text:
This has to be one of the best tasting potato soup recipes I've tried.  I think next time I will try adding some shredded cheese in the last step or stir some into a hot bowl of soup for an added kick.

I did find that this recipe takes much longer to prepare than the recipe states.  The times listed in the preparation are assuming you're starting out with peeled/diced potatoes, chopped onions, chopped celery, etc.  If you have none of this prepared ahead of time (and who does?) then this recipe will take much longer to make.  Sure, it's worth the time it takes to make it...but don't use this recipe for as last-minute dinner when you're in a hurry or when you're really tired and just wanting a good soup.  It took me about two hours to make this from start to finish.

The cooking of the potatoes in the middle of the recipe before the stock is added is an excellent step and it helps the potatoes cook much faster than they would have just by boiling alone.  The puree step at near the end is very important.  It highly affected the texture and flavor of the soup.  Don't skip that step!

Also, please don't think that "chicken broth" and "chicken stock" are the same thing.  They're not!  I wasn't able to find chicken stock at Walmart, I had to go to Albertsons.  If you use chicken broth you'll get a much different result.

I also noticed this recipe has no salt added.  I did find adding salt to my bowl of soup helped the flavor even more.  I suggest adding some salt!

I hi

text:
I read all the top reviews and nobody has mentioned this before so maybe it's not a big deal to some...but I thought the bacon would be SO much better if it wasn't boiled with the potatoes (after cooking it.)  It lost it's flavor and became soggy!  I think it would be so much better added at the end, after everything was pureed.  Just my $.02.

text:
Good base soup to build on for personal preference.  I felt the soup definitely lacked flavor, but wasn't sure if it was me, so I asked hubby to taste it.  Immediate response; "terrible"!  Thought he was kidding me, but alas, he was not....   Back to the stove top it went; added chicken boullion to give the soup more complexity and depth, extra garlic, white pepper (better with cream bases than black pepper), leeks, celery, garlic salt, tsp of hot pepper sauce, dried parsley and a tad bit more tarragon.  Didn't need to puree the soup as the potatoes melted away.  Ultimate potato soup with additions!

text:
This was by far one of the best Potato Soup recipes I've ever prepared!  It is a bit involved and time consuming (don't believe the prep or cook times posted here), but it was sooo worth it!  I added carrot and used chicken broth.  Yes, stock is better, but if you don't have it handy, broth works just fine.  If you've read any of my other reviews, you'll know I'm a fan of red potatoes, skin on; use them in this recipe as well!  In step 3 skip the pur√©e part.  It's a needless mess and complication!  Near the end, when the potatoes are soft, simply mash it about 4 to 5 times with a masher and achieve the same results, without the time, mess and added cleanup.  Top with your favorite grated cheese, sliced green onion and some crumbles of the bacon you've set aside.  Enjoy!

text:
Ultimate comfort food! I've made this recipe many times & it is always a hit with my family/friends. I personally don't care for tarragon, so i use rosemary instead of the tarragon & cilantro. Tip for those who are concerned with the amount of time spent chopping the veggies - i chop celery, onions & bell peppers up as soon as i buy them & put them in the freezer in zip lock bags. When I'm ready  to make this soup (or any other recipe) I just grab my pre-chopped vegs. from freezer and add them frozen to the pot.

text:
The Best!!  You'll add more tarragon once you taste test on the stove like I did.  It's the key.  To save dirty dishes, mess and time, don't remove half to puree, just send in the old fashioned "HAND" potato masher for 5 or so mashes.  You do not want to make mashed potatoes.  Hold off on throwing the bacon back in until ready to serve and let the person eating it add salt in their individual bowl to taste.  I'll make this recipe on a regular basis.
Thanks alot!!

None
text:
I adjusted this recipe to cook in my crockpot. My potatoes were organic reds, I just layered them in the crockpot covering with the organic broth and cooked them until fork tender, about four hours. I mushed the potatoes in the crockpot with my handheld potato masher leaving chunky bits, then added the crumbled bacon and the vegetables that I sauteed in a couple tablespoons of the bacon grease and a tablespoon of butter. I only needed about a 1/4 cup of fat free evaporated milk which left the soup thick without adding flour and creamy without being too fatty. This was good, but we didn't really care for the combination of tarragon and cilantro with the potatoes. It's not the recipe's issue, it's just our tastes, I guess.  Next time, I'll leave those out. This was an easy recipe to make in the crockpot which I appreciated.

text:
Excellent!  Never made potato soup before and this was quite a find.  Didnt use cilantro because quite honestly Im from Phoenix where everything has cilantro in it.  I will make it again adding it though.  Also I used 1/2 c. of 1/2 and 1/2 and a full cup of milk in lieu of the cream.  It is really a thick soup, I like my consistancy a little thinner.  Didnt puree the potatoes either, they cooked down quite nicely, so I just used a wire wisk to break them up a little more.  Used half bacon in the soup and saved the other half for topping.  All in all great flavor and very easy, thanks for the recipe!

text:
Gotta agree---this is the Absolute Ultimate Potato Soup!  We're in the middle of an ice storm here in southern PA.  There's already almost a foot of snow on the ground.  Seemed a perfect time to make this soup.  It is fabulous.  Working with what I had on hand (which was everything except heavy cream, cilantro & tarragon,) this soup turned out marvelous nonetheless.  I only used half a pound of bacon and that was perfect.  I added about a tablespoon of dried parsley to the roux and it worked well.  (I always have dried parsley flakes in my freezer---and chicken stock.)  I also substituted Half & Half for the heavy cream, but not in the interest of calorie-cutting.  It's just what I had on hand.  It, too, worked just fine.  Thanks, Karena, for sharing this wonderful, wonderful soup.

text:
That was very tasty.. I do plan to make it without the bacon added the next time and try it with butter as I thought it was a little heavy in the bacon flavor. I also added my flour to the potatoes when I added them to the pot to saute'.. then when I added the broth it blended quite nicely without the addition of another dirty pan to wash. I just added my lowfat cream and seasonings after boling the potatoes in the broth for about 18 minutes. I also didn't add the cilantro as I am allergic to it. I added a little sage and some chives instead. it was good that way.I will add bacon and cheese to the soup when serving it to give it a little bacon flavoring. This soup did take me about 2 and half hours to make. I will make it again, but this time with my changes. Thanks!!

I have not tried this recipe; but from reading it, and with 60 years of cooking experience, I can tell you that what it lacks is a touch of acid. I would add during the last 3 minutes cook-time, 1/4 cup GOOD white wine or if that is a problem for some cooks, some other acid - lemon juice in a lesser amount, or apple cider vinegar by a tablespoon.

text:
This potato soup was pretty good once I doctored it up.  I felt it needed a lot more salt than called for.  I also used dill instead of cilantro on the advice of other reviewers. It was easy to make  and came together quite well.  It was a little too thick, so I ended up adding additional milk to the recipe.  My only real complaint is that it doesn't do well as leftovers...it's the consistency of mashed potatoes and it needs to be thinned out so much when reheated, that it loses a lot of it's flavor.  I'll make this again, because it was delicious, but next time I will add more liquid, less flour and prolly add some carrots and corn.  I'll be making it to send with my hubby for hunting season!  Thanks for the recipe!
Review:
Rating:
5

2011-04-01T16:43:39.343

This was quick and easy to make for a delicious cream of potato soup.  I only changed a few things.  I only used 1/2 lb of bacon and 1/2 & 1/2 instead of cream.  you can problably use milk too if that is what you have on hand.  The potatos itself make the soup very creamy. You can even sprinkle some shredded cheddar on top too!!

My family considers itself potato soup connosieurs (sp?!) and they LOVED this!!!!!  I made a wonderful cheese bread to go with it on a cold, raw day, and my family ate it till they were stuffed.  My 4 year-old granddaughter, who rarely eats much of anything, came back later for two more bowls and literally licked the bowl!  It's calorious, but at least it's worth the calorie hit if you don't have it too often.  But watch out!  It can be addictive!!!

I will give it 4 stars because my hubby gobbled it up greedily, had seconds, and took some for lunch today. I didnt care for it though :-) Only because I dont really like bacon and to me it felt like I was eating bacon grease (I have NEVER cooked with bacon grease before!!!) I mean it tasted good for the most part, but I am somewhat of a health nut, so it was hard for me to eat this. OTHER THAN MY PHOBIA of bacon, it was a hit here. My hubby was so happy to have something not totally focused on healthy healthy healthy! He loved it. He thought it was perfect and delicious and is hoping I feel nice again and make it another time down the road! So if you like bacon, this just might be the soup for you!

text:
Thought it was great! I think it would be good as the recipe says, but I did make a few changes - leeks instead of onions; skim milk instead of cream; and skipped the flour. The soup was thick enough wo flour ... after the potatoes were soft, I mashed them up a bit, then just added milk. And I added at least 3 cups of milk, just to thin it a bit. Also, the tarragon made me nervous bc I don't really know a lot about tarragon, but I went for it and am glad I did! I think it's a nice, mild addition. Thanks for this recipe!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
I've adjusted this recipe a bit over a few batches. That said, the recipe is pretty good as-is.

Instead of cubing the potatoes and then blending the soup later, I used 7 shredded russet potatoes and 5 cubed gold potatoes, no blending. I think red potatoes would also be really good for cubing. Also I doubled the bacon and onion, added about a cup of shredded carrots, and used 1L chicken broth and topped it up with beef broth (about 500mL, enough to cover potatoes).

Also, FWIW, corn starch is much faster acting than flour as a thickener.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I am a traditionalist, I guess and although this soup was okay first time around. Left the tarragon, cilantro out and added flat leaf parsley.  I roasted the garlic since I like the mellow flavor imparted by the roasting.  Added a few red pepper flakes - only enough for flavor, left the skin on the potatoes and followed another users idea to use fat free 1/2 and 1/2 but only.  Mashed some of the potatoes (not all just some) rather than puree and still got the natural thickening from them. Didn't use the flour for thickenening as we have people with gluten allergies. Came out wonderful.  Only boiled for awhile at the beginning to cook the potatoes.  After that, because I used no flour, I only used medium setting heat.

text:
Great soup! I used a really lean bacon, Fat free 1/2 & 1/2, and instead of tarragon, I threw in a couple bay leaves. Also, a little trick I learned to thicken soup like this... no puree is needed, I just used a potato masher a few strokes and the soup is thickened perfectly without loosing any potato hunks.I like lots of potato in my potato soup and prefer the hunks of potato as opposed to a smooth soup. Also a great soup to experiment with...using chicken sausage, or ham, kielbasa...it all works well. You can also add Kale for an added nutritional boost. Mmmmm!

text:
This is very similar to my favorite potato soup recipe but I only use 2 or 3 slices of bacon, and half and half, rather than cream.  And instead of the tarragon and cilantro, try marjoram. You won't need much.  About 1/4 of a tsp. to start. It's such a nice spice in cream of potato soup and also cream of broccoli soup. Well worth experimenting with.

Delicious and don't be afraid to use bacon fat. Bacon fat/lard has 40% less saturated fat then butter. However it's about comfort factor and taste to me so I us a 50/50 mixture of butter and bacon fat for lots of things that I fry, brown or saute.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The idea of cooking everything in bacon grease was fabulous!  It lent a great smoky flavor to the soup, but I think next time I would just use the leftover fat (I saved it in the fridge) and not put in the bacon, because I don't particularly like the texture of it in the soup.  Or maybe add back the crispy bacon at the very end.  This is something I just decided to make on a whim and then realized I didn't have heavy cream or chicken stock, or celery, so I subbed in milk and chicken broth and tossed in some celery salt.  Skipped the tarragon and cilantro too, as I didn't have those either!  I added some sliced baby carrots to pretend I was having some vegetables with my dinner.  I decided at the last minute to toss in about 6 oz of cream cheese in the cream mixture, since I didn't use the cream.  I think that made all the difference in the taste of this one.  Very thick (I skipped the pureeing part as well) but very delicious!

text:
This recipe was delicious! Even my husband, who is a picky eater, loved it! I did have to change a few tings though for our families preferences. I added extra bacon, left out the celery and cilantro, since my husband wont eat them, and replaced tarragon with dried parsley and chives, since i didnt not have tarragon handy. I am giving this 5 stars because though I did make changes to the recipe I think this recipe could only be more delicious with the addition of the originally ingrediance, as long as you dont have picky eaters in your family like mine, haha. The previous reviewers do make an excellant point when saying the recipe takes much longer than 40 minutes. From begining to chop and prep everything to serving the soup took about 2 hours for me. So this is not a last minute meal, but when you have the time it is definately worth making!

country:
None
text:
MOST AMAZING POTATO SOUP EVER! Both my husband and I ("I" being the biggest critic out of the two) agreed this is the best potato soup we've ever had. I love putting extra work into my cooking, I'm not one for the "easy" recipes. If you don't do the steps the way it asks, I think it would disappoint you. I followed it exactly, and even added the taragon and cilantro bc although smelling the two on my chopping board didn't seem "right", it ended up being perfect - neither herb had any remote overpowering taste in the soup, very faint at that, but was just right, you could barely notice it really. I like my soups thick but this wasn't super thick or thin, it was really just right, and this was the PERFECT consistency. I have to be fair though and say that I did 2 things differently: 1, I didnt do the puree step. The reason being that when the whole soup was brought to a boil and that step came up, I tasted the soup, looked at the soup, and well, was just really happy with the way it was. 2, I added about a half cup of shredded sharp cheddar cheese and a tablespoon of black pepper. I LOVED this soup this way - but would be willing to give it a shot with the puree'd version and also omitting the cheese, just to see what happens. I am not even a cheese lover, but to me, I felt it would put this soup just right over the top in flavor, and it sure did. KUDO'S TO THIS RECIPE - FINALLY, POTATO SOUP DONE RIGHT! WOOHOO! ***DEFINITELY WORTH ALL THE EXTRA WORK*** Oh, and in regards to the

text:
YUMMO!!!  This soup is amazing!  Like some other reviewers, I did find it a little thick so I just added some milk.  I didn't blend any of it because when I stirred in the flour mixture the potatoes broke up perfectly, leaving just the right amount of chunks.  I only added about half the bacon to the soup, reserving the other half to sprinkle on top which I am glad I did.  I also sprinkled some cheese and green onions on top.  Oh, and I used half and half instead of heavy cream and it was plenty creamy.  And I had no cilantro but thought it was great without (will add it next time if I have some on hand, just didn't think it was worth buying just for this).  My boyfriend is already asking when I'm going to make this again!

text:
My husband and I loved it!  Very yummy.  My 9 year old said he didn't like the bacon in it.  Actually, next time I think I'll sprinkle crumbled bacon over the top of the soup instead of mixing it in, because it gets 'soggy' when it's cooked in (soggy bacon is not kid friendly!).  Also, I used 2% milk instead of cream and it was just as good I'm sure. There was no need to take out some soup and puree it.  It cooks right down with just the right amount of lumps of potato left in it without doing so, and it saves cleaning the blender too.  Didn't put in cilantro because didn't have it.

None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It's a super recipe as it is. 
I made some big changes to seriously skinny it down. First, I left in the bacon for smoky flavor -- but only used six strips of bacon and cooked it in a defatting pan. I omitted all but a tablespoon of the bacon grease or butter as called for. Instead of heavy cream, a mix of half skim milk and half nonfat sour cream was used. I used nonfat, low-sodium chicken broth. 

The result: a dieter's dream, and a pretty darn good potato soup.

text:
This is delicious. I add a carrot or two, shredded, and use milk instead of cream. I don't add cilantro, but do sometimes add fresh chives. I have even replaced half the potato with cauliflower to make it lower carb/lower calorie. If you puree the (cooked) cauliflower and leave the potato chunks, no one will know it's not all potato. Leftovers freeze well.

text:
I only made potato soup once years ago and wasn't happy with it. So since it's icy/snowy out I wanted a good creamy soup for dinner. I found this one and thought-bacon-he's favorite. I decided to make. I used leeks and green onion instead, and omitted the cilantro and other herb. I used parsley, garlic, salt/pepper, chicken stock. Followed the recipe, and used a half carton of cream since I made a large pot. When the recipe called for puree, I used a old fashion potato masher my Ya-Ya had to break up the chunks of potato. I also added shredded Monterrey jack, cheddar cheese when I served. I couldn't stop the "mmmm's" as we ate. It was delicious the best potato soup I have had. Can't wait to take some to the office to share! Wonderful warm soup for a cold wintery weekend! PS-I served w/ homemade twice stuffed potato skins. A little overkill on the starches...but sure was yummy!

text:
DELICIOUS!!!!!  I made this recipe and made a few changes.  I used chopped leeks in place of the onion.  I put chopped celery and leeks in the bacon drippings(1/4) cup and allowed them to cook/sweat, stirring occasionally ( 15 minutes or so) then I added the chopped garlic and let it cook a little longer then added cubed potatoes and let them cook about 5 minutes.  I poured the broth ( 2 cans as I did not have any chicken stock on hand).   I did NOT puree any of the soup; I JUST used a potato masher to mash up the potatoes a little as my family likes chunky soup.  I was hesitant to add the cilantro and tarragon but I DID!!!!  It made the soup 5 *!  You might need to add a little milk as it is VERY THICK!!!!  ENJOY!!!

text:
This was amazing. Just what I was looking for. We lived on the Oregon Coast all of our lives until recently moving to the Midwest. I have had trouble finding out how to make a good clam chowder base. Add clams to this recipe and you have an authentic clam chowder that can not be beat. And if you don't want clam chowder you can eat this just as the potato soup, it wont let you down. My only suggestion to others trying this recipe is be sure to get your bacon well done, not burnt but a little more crispy than you would normally like otherwise it will be rubbery in your soup. Other than that I can not preach how good this was. Thank you so much for sharing.

text:
Never made potato soup before but had some alterations to this recipe for our family.  Used Canadian bacon (also chopped) instead of greasy regular bacon ... used 2 Quarts home made chicken stock ... no garlic, tarragon or cilantro added.  Did add one well chopped carrot  and doubled the amount of potatoes ... no salt (we did add a bit at the table.  Changes in the directions ... used small amount of olive oil to onions when saut√©ing them and used hot water, cooked off, to finish them up same with the celery.  Followed directions for cream, flour and butter.  Did not puree but left chunks of potato.  Yummmy ... thin mashed potatoes with plenty of leftovers for sharing with sick friend's family.  Needed to be thinned with more cream or milk after sitting.   ;o)

text:
My family of picky eaters are all sick and I chose this to make for them for dinner and everyone LOVED it! I served it with sliced sweet french bread to dip and soak up the thick creamy soup and for it to be more filling for my big boys. I always double recipes due to large family and we love leftovers for lunch the next day. I did tweak the recipe a little. I used 2 lbs. bacon, 4 stalks celery, 2 lg. white onions, 6 cloves garlic, 16 potatoes, 2 49.5oz. cans chicken broth, 1 cube butter, 1c. flour, 1 quart heavy cream, 3 tsp. dried tarragon, 6 Tblsp. fresh cilantro, salt & pepper to taste. Same directions just more ingredients to feed my army:) Fantastic flavor! Wasn't sure about the cilantro but it fits fantastically. Will make again for sure!

text:
To reduce fat & calories, used precooked bacon in package (bacon bits aisle, but NOT bacon bits), saute celery, onion, bacon & garlic in 3 tbl's of light butter. Used fat free half n half in place of heavy cream & used FF chicken broth. Cut the calories & fat by almost half and the flavor was still great! After serving in bowls, topped with green onions and a little 2% ched cheese! (if want thicker soup, use a little corn starch & milk)

I have tried a lot of potato soups on this site and this is by far the best!  The flavor is just exquisite!
I did end up using more chicken broth than called for.  It was kind of an accident because I had homemade broth and didn't realize until later that I had used 10 cups instead of 4.  After reading the reviews though, I would recommend it.  It wasn't super thick.  Just creamy!

text:
I have mixed feelings regarding this recipe.  It is true that this soup is delicious, however the time involved and the constant attention needed during cooking was more than I thought it was worth, not to mention that as another reviewer stated, it also created many dirty dishes. It is a very "heavy" soup and therefore I would recommend using the half & half that other reviewers used instead of the heavy cream. My overall thoughts during the duration of making the soup was, "surely I can find a less time consuming recipe that will be good."  Unless you prefer "gourmet effort" or you need to wildly impress someone.

city:

country:
None
text:
This was labor intensive but fairly tasty.  It had a nice color, not the anemic color you would expect with a potato soup.  The color or course is due to cooking the soup in the same pot that you browned the bacon it.  The color was rich and the flavor was nice.  I omitted the tarragon and cilantro.  I garnished with thinly sliced green onion and crumbled bacon.  I served it with hot, crusty French bread.  It was quite tasty.  I found the "8 potatoes" ingredient listing a little vague.  I actully used a 5# bag of potatoes and 3 cans of chicken stock.  I used half the bacon and less than 1/4 c. bacon drippings, which may account for me needing to add salt.  I also added a little red pepper for zip.  I will make this recipe again.  My husband cleaned his bowl with his French bread!

text:
Absolutely amazing soup. I cooked the celery, onions and garlic in butter rather than the back on grease. I didn't want the whole soup to taste like bacon. I also fried the back on first than added it as a garnish or topping at the end so it maintained the crumbly crunchiness for the extra texture. I also didn't food process or mash any of the potatoes at the end. It was much better if a texture without that.

I make this soup (freezes well if you're making extra) all the time for my boyfriend and I! I use gold russet potatoes with the skin on for texture on those that don't get blended, I find it also cut down the cooking time. I also doubled the garlic and tarragon portion since we love lots of flavor! I also prefer ham chunks vs bacon. I used leftover ham from Christmas and it was mouth watering. Also a great way to use up leftovers!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6180387.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the best potato soup I have had and it is flexible enough to adjust to your taste. I have made it 4 times and every time it's been  a hit with family and company.  

I have made it without cilantro and terragon and it's still good. I add a little whole milk to stretch volume if someone extra shows up.

 I prefer to reserve half the bacon, crumble and add just before serving. This has some crunch as opposed to soggy bacon cooked in the soup itself. You may add grated cheese (or not) to serve.

 It is wonderful, versatile and very amenable to slight modifications. Don't cut the simmering time short (and don't turn heat too high). It tastes so much better if it can simmer for a good 40 minutes or so. Yum.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I wanted to really love this recipe, but I just couldn't.  Well, not without changing the recipe.  What did I dislike?  The prep time, for one thing.  You can achieve as good a result with butter (3-4 Tbsp), as you can with bacon grease.  And there's no cutting up a pound of bacon. Second, I think it was very bland.  I'm no salt addict, but I had to add two teaspoons or so, just to give it some flavor. What did I like? It was very creamy and comforting on a cold night. And, really, 1 C. of cream isn't all that much, considering the soup filled up my pot (a good 4 quarts).  I would change the herbs to something like an Italian seasoning blend, but that's personal preference.  Overall, it's a good base soup recipe.  It just needs more seasoning and flavor.

text:
Numma!  And the next time I make it I will substitute half of the broth with BEER!   I also have a tip for thickening up any soup.  Plain potato flakes, yes folks, really!  Simply sprinkle slowly and stir until desired consistency!  I use flakes for any creamy soup that I want to add substance to.

This recipe had too much of a strong fragrency spicy taste and smell.  When my husband came home he said what is that smell and I knew he smelled the tarragon that I smelled and we tasted it and that was all we could taste.  So I would omit that.  The next day the soup turned out to do exactly what the other review said it turned into mashed potatoes and was no longer a soup.  My husband suggested after the first night that I never make this again and maybe I will go witht the Kraft bacon potato soup and that only has 11 grams of fat vs 40 some grams of fat.  It was better the second day as mashed potaotoes, but you need antacids if you have stomach issues because there are just too many spices in there.  Was worth trying something new.

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love potato soup, and this one was very good.  I was true to the recipe except for substiting parsley for cilantro, adding more celery for some bite, more tarragon because we love it, and reserving the bacon separately to use at serving time so it didn't become limp.    One thing that surprised me was that the texture was great the first day I made it, but the leftovers turned into what can only be described as a pot of mashed potatoes.  So, in went 16 more ounces of chicken stock.  I did not use more than the recommended amount of flour in the roux, so I can only guess that the potatoes I used were larger than the ones used by the submitter (they were medium size ... not large).  That is one reason why I always prefer when I recipe calls for a number of pounds or cups, rather than just a number of items that can vary so much in size.  Maybe half and half should have been substituted for the heavy cream?  At any rate, I would advise having more chicken stock on hand in case this happens to you.  Thank you, Karena, for the recipe!

text:
I made this recipe twice and as written, I give the recipe 3.5-4 stars. It's a good starting point but the taste leaves me wanting more flavor. I modified the soup to increase the garlic to 6 cloves and I also added about 1 tsp of dried basil (alone) and about 2 tsp of Italian seasoning mix (blend of dried basil, oregano, rosemary, marjoram, cilantro, thyme, red pepper flakes). My family and friends loved the soup and I will definitely make the modified version again!

2007-06-16T17:38:32.983

userID:
2392986
Display Name:
KitchenBarbarian
isPro:
False
followersCount:
24
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
49
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/37006.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I originally reviewed this on Jun. 16, 2007.  I have made it many many times since. The flour called for in the recipe is totally unnecessary and in fact is detrimental to the overall quality of the soup.  The naturally occurring starches in the potatoes themselves are more than sufficient to thicken the soup. When using the flour, leftovers or frozen portions will become grainy.  Just leave it out - it is totally unnecessary. The additional butter is no longer needed either. Also, half a pound of bacon is more than sufficient for 8 med size russet potatoes.

This is the recipe that made me stop hating potato soup. I made it for my Dad, and after he had tasted it, he said, "You know, when I was watching you make that, I didn't think it would be worth all the trouble, but it sure is!" DON'T leave out the tarragon or the cilantro - if you do, you just won't know what you're missing! I get Tarragon in a 5 g container from McCormick or Best Buy for .89 to 1.19 - much cheaper than the fancy stuff in the glass bottles. You can also find the tarragon much more affordably from a place like Penzey's, and it has many other uses (such as in seasoning roasted potato wedges).

Finally, the prep time is WAY off.  This soup takes much longer than 10 mins prep time - closer to 20 to 30 minutes. Altogether it takes about an hour to prepare and cook this soup.

I give it 3 stars as-is, but 5 stars if you leave out the flour and just mash up some of the potatoes in the soup instead.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2007-01-07T17:25:00.477

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this soup last night for dinner, and my family and I loved it!  The texture turned out just right and the flavoring with the bacon was just yummy!  I have to say, though, that the prep time listed was completely off -- (Prep Time: approx. 10 Minutes. Cook Time: approx. 30 Minutes. Ready in: approx. 40 Minutes.)  I am a big fan of cooking soup and often spend all day in my kitchen making huge batches to freeze and eat all during winter, so when I saw this soup listed as taking 40 minutes I thought "cool, I can make this for dinner on Tuesday night with steak sandwiches!"  Well, I would suggest adding an hour on to the prep time -- just chopping the raw bacon, cooking it, peeling and cutting the potatoes and chopping the cilantro took me 40 minutes -- and I already had chopped onion from Sunday's soup-maiking day and used reconstituted dehydrated minced garlic.  So, by all means, make this soup, it's well worth the effort.  But if you are a working mother and want your family to eat before 8:30 at night, make it on the weekend!

country:
None
text:
I changed a few things in this recipe. I just boiled the potatos in the chicken broth, not sauteing them. While they cooked I got the other ingredients ready.  Since the potatoes had a longer cooking time, they thickened enough not to need the butter/flour mixture.  I used ¬Ω lb. bacon and ¬Ω lb. smoked link sausage, 2% milk instead of cream, and 1 cup shredded smoked gouda cheese, and 1 cup shredded cheddar. Also added a can of cream of mushroom soup. Followed the rest of the recipe, though.  I wanted to trim a few calories, if possible.  I patted the grease from the bacon and sausage and used olive oil to saute. It was a hit with the family. I do plan to try this going strictly by the recipe.

text:
This soup is awesome! I've made it twice.Both times using 1/2 & 1/2.Used russets the first time,just mashed the potatoes right in the pot and did'nt have to thicken at all.It was a little mealy with the russets but I loved it just the same.Tonight I tried it with red potatoes.Though it was very good,I did have to thicken it.Screwed up the flour mix so just added some instant potatoes to thicken.I thought I would prefer a creamier soup but I preferred the texture of the russets and it's less work.Also,I dont bother making broth,just add the water and throw Knorr cubes in the pot.(Don't like the regular boullion cubes,they just seem like salt water).

Great recipe, however I too had to cut back on the bacon by half. I guess if you really like the taste of bacon you could leave it alone but I only wanted a hint of bacon flavor, not for it to be the dominate flavor. This was my first time using tarragon in potato soup. It was a bit loud, but it wasn't unpleasing. I was suprised at how well it complimented the soup. I used fresh instead of dry so that may have been the problem. Going to have to play with this one until I find the right amout for my taste. But overall this recipe is fantastic.

text:
I did make some changes and it turned out fabulous, so I don't really know exactly how it would have turned out if I had followed the recipe exactly.  I cooked the bacon, onions and celery as it says.  I cooked the potatoes separately in a pot with canned chicken broth, then added my sauteed onion and celery.  After that had cooked for a while, I added a box of frozen peas & carrots and frozen corn.  At the very end, I added a can of cream of mushroom soup and the bacon.  Served with grated cheese on top.  It is delicious!  I didn't add the seasonings because the chicken broth was seasoned already.  I will definately make my version again!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
An exceptionally easy, tasty potato soup. I made some modifications, otherwise it would get 5 stars. I don't eat meat, so I left out the bacon drippings. I cut the amount of butter WAY back, used some olive oil for part of the fat I did keep, and used fat free half and half instead of the cream to make a lighter, healthier soup. For those who said the soup was too thick, the solution is painfully simple- just puree a smaller amount of the soup, say 1/4 of the soup rather than 1/2.  This froze well and we enjoyed it for a couple weeks after I made it.

text:
The flavor is amazing.  Next time I will be keeping the cooked bacon out and using it as a topping to mix in while eating.  Adding the bacon into the soup at the stage it says to, rehydrates the bacon, making any fat bits a blubber mess.  I ate around the bacon pieces this time but will remember that change next time.  Will make again for sure.  I also used dried cilantro since I did not have fresh.  Still really good!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/36361.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Phenomenal soup!   Two Notes:   First, be sure to use stock and  not broth.   Broth is made with a lot of meat and stock is made with more bones, and bones release gelatin which increases the liquid's richness.   It makes a world of difference!    Stock stock stock, that's the way to go.      Second, modify the bacon.  Instead of returning it to the dish in Step 2, add it back to the soup at the very end.    Flavor isn't enhanced, but the texture is superior, in my opinion.   By adding it back at the end, the bacon is crisp instead of limp.
Review:

text:
My daughter and I love potato soup, so we are always looking for new recipes.  This one is a keeper.  I made this in my pressure cooker (electric).  I did not use the bacon (we are more vegetarian) so I sauteed the onion and celery in 3T butter (on brown in my pressure cooker), then added the broth and red potatoes.  While this was cooking, I made the rue without tarragon and cilantro.  Once done, I added corn then mashed some of the pototoes.  We made homemade croutons, added black pepper and dome DILL for freshness.  Topped with shredded cheese and gobbled this up.  I am going to make this for my soup exchange and may add the bacon on the side if people want to add this themselves.

text:
I have made several different versions of potato soup and this is my new favorite! I used chicken broth instead of stock, I used a masher to mash some of the potatoes right in the pan instead of pureeing, I used half and half instead of heavy cream, and I omitted the tarragon and cilantro (didn't have any.) It still tasted awesome! My husband and two boys had seconds! The consistency and taste was perfect. Yes, the prep was a bit of work, but it was worth it.

text:
Following the recipe given made for an extremely bland, boring soup, even with the bacon.

I tried again, this time adding about a cup of shredded cheddar, some smoked chilli powder, about five more cloves of garlic, some diced mushrooms, and lots of green onions.  

I also skipped the cilantro and went with some fresh rosemary instead. I ended up with something much more hardy, tasty, and comforting than the recipe gave me.

text:
I made this but did a few modifications. I did not have Tarragon but used an Italian seasoning mix instead. The Italian seasoning had Tarragon, dried basil leaves, marjoram, oregano, and rosemary in it. Also, used dried cilantro as I did not have fresh. I used Bacon Salt with a bit of Sea Salt. The last thing I did was not Puree anything as I think the hearty texture looks and taste great.
It came out REALLY GOOD! I believe the different salts were a nice touch!

text:
2/16:  very good.  a few changes.  i used scallions instead of onion and just a little but either one would be fine.  i used 2 slices of bacon only because only 2 of us were having crumbled bacon on top.  i did not mix the bacon in with the soup, i think that wouldn't have been good.  for the roux, i used 1/2 cup heavy cream and 1/2 cup half and half and it was way too thick.  after combining in the soup and pureeing, i had to add 2 cups of boiling water with one chicken cube in it to thin it out.  i used dried cilantro.  needed more flavor at the end so i added dried mustard, cayenne pepper, salt and ground pepper.  alot of each.  then it was very good.  matthew, larry and i all like it with bacon on top and crountons.

text:
Very tasty, but I would say it takes 45 minutes to an hour to make. I like bacon crispy especially when it needs to be crumbled. Since I needed to pur√©e the potato mixture (in several batches due to blender capacity), I didn't add the bacon until I was done with that. Also, the cream mixture doesn't need to be started until you're close to done pureeing. I didn't have tarragon, so I used dill and loved it! Garnish with some shredded cheddar cheese and sour cream.

text:
The soup takes an hour plus to make but is worth the effort. I put some bacon in when I cooked the potatoes and reserved some for garnish. I shipped the pur√©e step which really isn't necessary unless of course you like to be able to drink your soup. I used red potatoes which are small and they cook relatively fast so if you desire, you can break them up with a wooden spoon. I did make the roux which added the thickness. The day I made it we were getting pounded by snow (expecting 6 inches) so this is perfect for that kind of day!

text:
Soup was all right the first time I made it, but had way too much cilantro/taragon for my family's tastes and the bacon came out mushy. The second time I made it with 1/4 TSP of cilantro, taragon, oregano, and basil... 1/2 tsp of pepper and salt, mixed them in while the garlic was simmering along with 1/2 cup of butter. I also didn't add in the bacon until the very last step the second time around, and the soup came out much better. Family loved the edited version.

text:
Yum! This is definitely a good potato soup base to build on. I found it to be quite flavorful as written, although I didn't have tarragon so substituted a mix of fennel seed, ground marjoram, rosemary, and oregano. I also added carrots to the veggies, and I used an immersion blender (love that thing!) to blend it without mess. I did need more than 1 cup of liquid to make the cream sauce. I used 1 cup heavy cream and the roux was still very solid, so I thinned with milk (prob another 1/2 cup) until it was a nice sauce. And it only took me about 1 hr start to finish, even with chopping veggies.

text:
I just throw all the ingredients in the pot and simmer for an hour-ish, reserving the flour until the end, use just enough to thicken, then a few pokes with the potato masher to mash a few of the potatoes. I can't tell a difference in the end result doing it this way rather than saut√©ing and all that. I omit the tarragon as I don't care for it,  only use cilantro when I have it on hand, and I brown and serve the bacon on the side as a garnish.  I know the rating police will hate a review of a recipe I didn't explicitly follow directions on, but oh well. Cooking entails experimentation - get over it.

city:

country:
None
text:
Great base recipe, however I made a few simple changes. I made the bacon, but didn't use as directed in the first step of the recipe I set aside and added later. I combined the celery, onion and garlic in a pot and cooked for 3-4 minutes then added the potatoes and chicken stock and allowed to cook until the potatoes were tender. In the next step I combined the butter, flour, heavy whipping cream and substituted the tarragon and cilantro with 1 1/2 TSP of Rosemary then combined it with the potato mixture. No need to puree the potatoes just a few simple passes with the potato masher worked just fine. I then added in the bacon to the mixture and allowed to simmer for another 5 minutes. Before the last 3 minutes of simmering I added 3/4 jar of Cheese Whiz and 1/2 cup of Sharp Cheddar cheese (shredded). My husband and 2 very picky boys LOVED IT!

I added thyme and salt and pepper instead of cilantro and tarragon.  Also I omitted chicken stock and cooked potatoes and onion with just enough water to barely cover potatoes.  Let them cook until tender and no need to puree or add flour, still lumpy and great.  Just before serving add butter and crumbly bacon.  I also browned a little ground sausage and added that.  It's a favorite with friends and family.  A meal indeed with warm crusty bread.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe though I tweaked it a bit on multiple repeats.  
Cook as above saving a few slices of bacon raw. Once cooked bacon is removed add raw bacon to soup for added bacon flavor. Do not return the crisped bacon to the pan until the soup is finished.
-To reduce fat, evaporated milk works well instead of cream. Liquid smoke can be used for 'bacon' flavor without the fat. Saute in coconut or other vegetable/olive oil for a healthier alternative. 
-To make this meat and dairy free,saute in coconut oil, substitute one can coconut milk and 2 tsp. coriander seed and dash of cayenne instead of smoky flavor.

text:
Excellent basic recipe, which you can easily adjust for quantity, taste and calorie count. Homemade chicken stock will provide a different, possibly more concentrated flavor. I nixed the cilantro and added more fresh garlic, plus a few more personal choices (fat free evaporated milk, fresh cracked pepper, etc.) and served with warm whole wheat bread, garlic butter with shredded cheese (sharp cheddar)& minced green onion available. Tweak away... they will gobble it up! Oh, I dropped a star for overall prep time and IMO avoidable calorie/bad fat count.

Display Name:
Mtnlaurl

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674137.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been making this recipe for several years and decided it was time to review it. Obviously, it's become a staple in my household. It's a very forgiving recipe as I sometimes don't use the whole pound of bacon and I never add the tarragon or cilantro as I have family members who aren't fond of either. I substitute with fresh parsley. I will use celery seed - sauteing them with the onions - if I don't have celery. I find that the celery flavor is important to the dish as a whole. In lieu of flour I have used a tablespoon or so of instant mashed potato flakes to thicken up the soup. We garnish with the bacon, with more parsley, or with shredded cheese. Combined with a grilled cheese or ham sandwich and you've got a perfect dinner for a cold night. In fact, there's a pot of this on my stove right now which prompted me to finally review it. It's excellent!

Yummy! I increased butter and flour to 1/3 c each and used 1 3/4 c of half n half so I could add about 1 c shredded 
cheddar cheese. I omitted the cilantro and replaced w/ fresh chopped chives, about 1 1/2 Tablespoons and increased my garlic to 6 cloves. Puree half the soup its well worth it in the creamy dept. I topped our bowls w/ teaspoon sour cream, fresh coarsely chopped green onion and a sprinkle of cheddar. GREAT comfort food!
Thanks for the recipe.

city:

country:
None
text:
This is a good soup.  After reading the reviews I can see how the recipe would be bland if broth was used instead of stock.  There is a big flavor difference between them.  I did add more salt and a bit of red pepper flake, and used 1/2 & 1/2 to cut the fat. The amount of salt depends on the stock used.  I did not use flour but thickened the soup with corn starch for my gluten free eaters.  I did not cook with the bacon grease but did top the soup with sharp cheddar and bacon.  I made my kids do the chopping while I was cooking the bacon so it didn't take as long as some suggested.  My family liked it.

This turned out fantastic.  I stuck pretty close to the recipe, although I added 8 oz Velveeta into the flour and cream, with about a half cup of milk to thin it out.

My family heartily enjoyed this with shredded cheese & scallion garnish.  I will definitely make this again!

text:
This is a great base recipe!  Even though I had some doubts about some of the aspects of this soup, I made it exactly how the recipe is written.  Next time, I would do the following: add some carrots (only because I love carrots in soup), omit the tarragon and cilantro (not sure how felt about the flavor of it in the soup) and add some cayenne pepper.  I would also not puree the soup....seemed thick enough on its own and after pureeing, I had to cut the soup down with additional chicken stock.  Still gave it five stars...very yummy!

I'm at a loss for words to describe how delicious this potato soup is.  My oldest grandson who is 14 said "Ganny, this is the best!" You mean the best potato soup? "No the best soup I have ever eaten!" Our entire family loved it and are still raving about it.  I'm afraid they're going to ask for it again soon and my only complaint is that it is NOT 10 minute prep time.  With my husband and I both working steadily at the preparation and cooking, it took over two hours to prepare it but it was WELL worth it.  I only wish I could take credit for it.  We fixed it exactly according to the recipe and although I wouldn't change a thing, there are many substitutions and/or additions one could make depending on your tastes or your desire for fewer calories.  But just know that it is GREAT just the way it is written.  The only things we added were a little salt and pepper.  Karena, I hope you have more recipes posted because I'm going looking for them right now.

region:

country:
None
text:
They make potato soup at my job. I went to the website to find a recipe to fix at home. The first one I tried contained sour cream. I didn't like it so I tried this one. Lots of work and more time than stated but the results were perfect. Just like I like it. I left out the herbs and added more stock and half and  half as it was very thick. Will try suggested garnishes and add some carrots next time. Didn't need anymore seasoning for me as I don't use very much salt. The bacon gives it flavor and if you're like me you can always tweak it. I used Better than Boullion chicken stock and will try some parsley or chives next time as well.This is a keeper. Add a salad and some hot crusty french bread and you'll think you've died and gone to heaven.

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I Absolutely agree - fabulous soup! I have been searching for years for this recipe.  I did make a couple of changes but just for personal preference.  I don't like tarragon so just went with the cilantro, which I love, plus sea salt and ground pepper.  I also did not puree any of the soup - instead I added 2 cups real  leftover mashed potatoes just after the cream.  I  have always hated the flour taste in most cream soups so I just added the butter after the cream and along with the mashed potatoes it thickened up just fine.  It did not need the roue (flour & butter mixture). Anyway, it was fabulous!  I also have a hint for those who, like me, may not be familiar with all the herbs & spices out there.  I went on google and put in "tarragon taste"  - a site came on and told me what tarragon tastes like - it included licorce  which is a flavor I detest.  So I am glad I checked before I bought some and used it.  If you're not familiar with an herb, check it out before you buy it since it might ruin a recipe for you and also they can be very expensive.  The Internet can be a wonderful helper sometimes.

text:
This is very, very good! I didn't have cilantro on hand so I substituted some basil, parsley & a dash of mint- it was excellent & I'll probably continue to use that modification! I put half of the cooked bacon into with the potatoes to simmer. I pureed about half of the soup and felt it was too thick so I added 1 can of chicken broth- it was nice & creamy and still had nice chunks of potatoes! We crumbled the remaining half of the bacon over our bowls & sprinkled cheese on top... delicious!! I will definitely make this again.

text:
Um...WOW!  Way YUM!   I wouldn't change a single thing about this recipe, except the time it takes to prepare.  But a little time investment yields a simply divine soup. To speed up the process a bit, I cooked the bacon in a large electric skillet and then started the vegetables in the dutch oven as soon as I had rendered enough of the bacon fat. The bacon finished cooking at the same time the vegetables were in process.

text:
I halved the recipe and only used 4 slices of bacon. This made just enough grease to saute the veggies and add a light bacon flavor.  I ate two and saved the others to add to the soup. I don't like tarragon and didn't want the taste of cilantro in my soup so I used chives and parsley.  I used red skinned potatoes which I think hold their shape better and they don‚Äôt give the soup a grainy texture.  The recipe turned out very well and comes together quickly.  I had planned on only eating a small cup of the soup but it was so good, I ate two cups.  I decided to add a little shredded cheddar to the second serving.  Delicious!

text:
I thought this recipe was quite good, although not quite what I expected.  It is by far the best soup I've made besides cream of broccoli.  I usually have trouble with the thickening step- I wish there was some way I'd know if I did it right- but it seemed pretty thick after I mashed the soup with my potato masher (pureeing sounded like something that would go terribly wrong).  I really wasn't sure how long to cook the bacon, and since I used leeks instead of onions (milder yet still flavorful for my poor stomach) I wasn't sure how long to let them saute, but I do think it was tasty and my boyfriend weally liked it.  I have a feeling he would be sold on anything with bacon!

text:
I made several adjustments to this soup since I am vegetarian, I used a 'no-chicken chicken broth' no bacon, and Silk Coffee creamer plain flavored.  I also used the small golden onions whole to saute and simmer in the soup, I also added carrots and dried shittake mushrooms.  The carrots gave it a slight sweet taste, which was delicious and the mushroom were good as well.  I pureed about 1/3 of it and it worked well.  The flour didn't mix well with the creamer, so I ended up removing it, next time I will either try using soy flour or none at all.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have looked through many recipes for potato soup, but the name save it all.  This is absolutely the ultimate potato soup.  Don't be tempted to leave anything out.  It all comes together in the end.  My one suggestion for the bacon, is to cut it up in small chunks first with kitchen sheers, and then brown it to a crisp.  When it's time to add it back in, I only add in half, and reserve the other half to spinkle on top when serving, along with shredded cheese and chives.  If you can find chicken stock instead of broth, use it.  It has so much more flavor!  It takes a lot of time to prepare this, but it is so worth it!

Pretty good, I added 1/2 tsp thyme and only used 1/2 tsp tarragon (wasn't sure about licorice flavored soup). So next time I make it, no pureeing, no bacon in soup, only for garnish. Oh also added a shredded carrot, added color and taste, and no cilantro.

Original review 10/25/2005 - This is truly the ultimate potato soup recipe. I will never make another. DO NOT CHANGE A THING when making this soup. It is perfect exactly the way it is. I have made it many times and each time it is gone within a day. I get raves reviews from everyone I've made it for. Thank you so much for this fabulous recipe.

UPDATE 12/31/2015: I can't tell you how many times I've made this awesome soup but every time it turns out thick and delicious. I give it away as gifts and everyone always has great things to say about it.  I have never used cilantro or tarragon because I do not have those things on hand and won't buy them for one recipe, but it so, so good without them so I personally will never add them. Delicious and well worth the prep time!

text:
Very good... I wish this recipe specified what kind and size of potatoes to use. I used red potatoes and since they are less starchy, they got a bit glutenous when I blended the soup. I would also suggest eye-balling the amount of bacon grease you use. I thought 1/4 cup was too much. Another suggestion I have is to try omitting the butter/flour and use Wondra (made by Gold Metal) instead to thicken the cream mixture. Also, I don't see any reason why you couldn't use 2percent or whole milk intead of cream. This was tasty in it's hi-fat form, but would probably be just as good with these changes.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
What a wonderful soup! I am vegetarian so I used the butter option, but I have a *secret* - when you finally add the potatoes to the onion mixture, sautee it for about a minute and then add about 1/4 cup of BACOS Bacon Flavored Bits. They are not real bacon, they are a soy substitute. That will add back the bacon flavoring. I did not add cilantro; the tarragon was a brilliant addition I wouldn't normally have thought of. Also I used half and half instead of the heavy cream, and I used my blender to puree half of the soup. I served fresh warm rolls with butter with this soup. HEAVEN!

text:
I frequently use this recipe and it always receives rave reviews.  However, to make this soup a bit healthier, I substitute the bacon for light margarine and use skim milk instead of the heavy cream.  I've never felt that I've missed out on anything using skim milk, but then again, I've never made it with the heavy cream to know otherwise.  And I use 99% fat-free chicken broth.  Also, I've made this recipe with as well as without cilantro and the difference isn't great enough that I would go out of my way to buy any if I don't have any on hand when making this.  With these modifications, I don't need to make these as a "special treat."  I can make this as often as I feel like it!  This is an Excellent recipe!!!

The soup was delicious! But it was brownish, I guess I had visions of cream colored soup.  But that might have been my fault.  I browned the bacon, deglazed the pan with a very small amount of (white) port wine.  When I pureed 1/2 of the soup and added it back in the soup was not cream colored it kinda looked more like a light gravy. Hmmm. But still delicious.  I'm thinking that if I want a cream colored soup :-), I should use smoked ham for the smokey flavor and cook the bacon separetly from the soup and sprinkle crumbled bacon on top? text:
This is an awesome potato soup.  I've made it for several different guests and everyone always wants the recipe.  After making this many times, I've started using just a bit more garlic and a little red pepper for some kick.  One helpful tip:  Don't overcook your bacon--I did this once and it just didn't seem as good.  When it's just starting to crisp, you're ready to go.  Comfort food at it's best!

text:
The recipe is good, but I was not prepared for all the prep work. Maybe it was because I was making dinner while helping the kids with homework, snack etc. In addition to the all the prep, the recipe has you make the cream after you get the soup cooking. I should have waited 10-15 minutes before starting that part of the recipe. I had it finished and had to let it sit. I added some of the stock to it when I was ready to add into the soup, it warmed it up and thinned it down. My husband didn‚Äôt like the Tarragon flavor next time I will leave that out, I did not add the cilantro because my family does not like it. I used half and half instead of cream and it worked great.I would wait to put the bacon in, a lot gets blended up and that is my kids favorite part.

text:
This one's a keeper.  I've made it countless times.  I have tweaked it however--I omitted the tarragon and cilantro (didn't have any on hand and thought it sounded strange to add those herbs anyway)  AND I don't put any of the cooked bacon back into the broth to cook with the potatoes.   I simply serve the yummy crunchy bacon on top of each bowl.  Putting it in the broth only renders it soft and less appealing.   Give this one a try!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
The only time I make a potato soup recipe is when I have a small bowlfull of left-over mashed potatoes. If you use flour to thicken this soup, this is no longer soup, it's something else - a stew. I use thyme leaves and parsley for flavoring, plus salt and pepper,  but you can use whatever flavorings you like. I put in diced potatoes, raw, a diced carrot, and one can cream of chicken soup (last) along with the chicken broth. Otherwise just follow the recipe as is. I don't use the cream as the mashed potatoes have milk in them if you're watching the calories.

text:
Outstanding soup.  On second attempt made the following changes and liked it even better: Used about 1/3 of the bacon to make bacon crumbs to sprinkle on top.  Added 4 Brown'n Serve breakfast sausages sliced in 1/4 inch pieces to the other 2/3 pound bacon in the recipe.  Added cooked bacon/sausage at the end to keep them from getting chewy.  Pureed only 1/3 of the soup (instead of half) - the original recipe was actually too thick.  I can't resist tinkering - Karena's original recipe was great and you may prefer it.

text:
I loved the flavor. It was wonderful and it is full of flavor NOW. I know it will taste better tomorrow but you dont have to wait. I made a few modifications only because it is what I had handy. I used the precooked bacon and threw it in the pan and let it get crunchy then drained. It leaves a little fat in the pan, then I put in the onion and celery and sauted then a little butter and then the garlic and made every thing golden. I dont care for cilantro except for in salsa so I omitted it. I cant tell you how great this is. I chopped the tops of green onions and sprinked on top and then crumbled some of the held back bacon for the top. Then three small shavings of cheese. And Viola.....Dinner is served! Thanks

This one will be a standard now for our family...I served it at a dinner party for 8 (doubled the recipe so that we could freeze the rest) and received rave reviews. text:
We loved this soup!  Admittedly it is not for the faint hearted, but such a wonderful treat!  I substituted the bacon with diced ham that I had left over from a baked ham, and, used the ham fat to saute my veggies.  Also, I added some carrots for color and shredded cheese (of choice) for an extra creamy texture.  Just a wonderful base recipe to then personalize to your family's tastes.  Believe me, there were no left overs!

text:
This is the best potato soup recipe ever!!  I have made this soup at least a dozen times for different occasions and everyone begs for the recipe!!  I don't like the bacon grease, so I use canned, crumbled bacon and instead use olive oil.  I also use half and half instead of the heavy cream, although milk would be fine as this soup is very thick.  One last favorite addition of my fiance's is cheddar cheese!!  Everyone should try this recipe once and they will be hooked!!

None
text:
I have made this recipe twice to the rave review of my friends.  As I do not like the grease and heavy
flavor associated with regular bacon, I substitute turkey bacon in the recipe.  In place of the grease, I
use a little olive oil.  The taste is wonderful, and the reduced fat content makes you feel a little better 
about eating the soup.  Be careful about over-stirring, as it can break down the potatoes and give the
soup a rather mashed-potato texture.  Enjoy!

text:
I had to make some changes based on what I had on hand. Wasn't going to the store on a cold day to pick up a couple of ingredients, so had to improvise. I didn't have any cream, so used some cream cheese and omitted the flour. I used rosemary instead of tarragon. I didn't add the bacon until the very end because I like it crunchier. I also added some carrots and then at the end, added some shredded cheddar cheese. I just mashed the potatoes with a masher instead of my inversion blender. I also added a bit of better than bouillon to my broth for more flavour. Husband was standing over the stove eating it right out of the pot, with the serving spoon. Needless to say, he loves it, and since I made it for him, that's all that matters.

text:
Turned out delicious! I omitted the tarragon and cilantro.  Cooked about 6 thick slices of bacon, garlic, onions, and celery together.  Then added chopped potatoes until slightly browned. Added a couple dashes of onion powder, black pepper,  and salt. Put all into 4 cups of chicken broth. Whisked butter with flour added heavy whipping cream until thickened. Added to potato soup and wahala.  Master piece. It is bacon potato soup.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was pretty good. I'll make some changes next time, though.
  
First, the onions and celery were a bit overpowering.  The bacon helped to balance out the onions and it wouldn't hurt to have even more bacon.  Next time I will make sure to caramelise the onions, roast the garlic, and try adding less celery.  Also, "8 potatoes" can vary wildly depending on the size and type of potato.  It would be better if the recipe had a weight measurement of potato.  I needed twice the amount of broth that the recipe called for in order to manage my 8 potatoes.  Overall, this is a good recipe, even though it could use some tweaking depending on personal taste.

text:
This is a great starting point. I thought the original recipe was a bit bland so I added some bay leaves into the potato and stock along with the seasons so they had a chance to really build flavors. I also put pepper in while the potatoes cooked.   The prep time is longer than the recipe says and if you want to really get a good flavor let the potato mixture cook for a while before adding cream mixture.  I also held the bacon out until the end and topped with shredded cheese.  It was a hit.

text:
This is probably the best potato soup recipe I've made (and I've tried alot of them!). The only change I made was to use half the amount of potatoes and sub in sliced carrots and corn for the difference.  Also, the butter, flour, cream mixture for me quickly turned more to a paste than sauce consistency even though I was stirring it constantly and only cooked for the time cited.  However, once I whisked it into the soup, it was fine.  I did let it all simmer together on Lo with the lid on for about 10 minutes at the end.  I highly recommend this recipe.

text:
Remember folks, a recipe is not set in stone but a guideline. Then it can be tweaked for your taste. After reading many reviews and hints I applied a few to the original recipe. One thing I found is not to use baking potatoes, they just don‚Äôt work. Tarragon is one of my favorite herbs so I added a little more. With friends over for lunch, they loved it. Yes, it does take time with the peeling and chopping so I made it the night before. It thickened up overnight and I just stirred in water before heating. Very nice recipe.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great starter recipe. I modified this recipe to be dairy-free and gluten free for my household. To replace the flour and heavy cream, I made a cashew cream (cashews and water blended in nutribullet).  For additional flavor I cooked chopped leek root (the part below the "leaves") with the onion and celery. Blending part of the potato mixture with the cashew cream and cilantro is key to melding and distributing flavor throughout the soup. We topped the soup with chopped leek leaves. My kid loved this soup.

text:
Loved this!!! Made it as written only substituting parsley for the cilantro as we are those people that don‚Äôt enjoy cilantro. Not sure why so many people complained about the timing of the recipe.  Calls for 50 minutes and it took me 60 first time as I kept looking back to double check ingredients and steps. Don‚Äôt waste your time preparing everything first. Cut the bacon. While that‚Äôs cooking I cut the vegetables, making sure to cut the onion and celery first. I had onion, celery and 2 potatoes done by the time the bacon was done. Finished the last of the potatoes while the onion and celery cooked. Time management*. Great recipe. Next time I might add some green onion and some bacon on the side for garnish to make it look pretty.

text:
So, I have made this recipe several times and it is excellent! 

Today I  Was in a jamb having several potatoes that I needed to use before they went bad. I  pulled this recipe up yet again.  When I opened the refrigerator to pull out the needed ingredients, I realized I had a decent size sirloin steak left over from the grill a couple of days ago. It was on the rare side. Lol, I  just went with it!

Cubed seared steak  instead of bacon, beef stock instead of chicken. I tossed a few cut baby carrots from fridge in with the potatoes and added about a cup if sliced marinated mushrooms from a huge jar we are constantly noshing on at the last minute. Had to use half and half instead of cream.

 When it was all done, I topped it with a fine shred Mexican cheese blend. OMG, I keep going back to the pot!! Lol, that man of mine better not be late getting home from work, there might not be any left!!

I used russet potatoes because that's what I had on hand. Even my picky little eater is loving it and is on her second bowl.

country:
None
text:
The soup was really good the SECOND time I made it. The first time, I made the recipe as written and it was nothing to write home about. I made a few corrections the second time and it turned out amazing. Here are the corrections - do not add the bacon to the soup!  Save the crispy bacon as a topping with cheese and green onions when served. Do not add tarragon and cilantro!  The tarragon flavor in the first batch was overwhelming and ruined the soup. DO add salt and white pepper to taste. This requires a lot of salt to balance the potatoes. The second batch with the corrections listed was great!

text:
I made this but I did alter it so I will say that up front.  What I like best about this is it is from scratch as much as you can do it these days.  No soups or soup mixes.  Most stocks are pretty simple without a lot of additives.  I really cook from scratch most of the time to avoid the additives in so many premade items.  When you do this often you will start to taste the additives when you use them and it is not a good taste.  Great soup recipe and can be adjusted to suit individual taste.

text:
I‚Äôll preface by letting you know I never follow recipes exactly. I use them as a guide or idea. I looked for a great potato soup recipe because I‚Äôve never found anything thick and creamy enough. This one is! Pureeing half the soup was genius! I didn‚Äôt have celery so I used celery flakes and different seasonings based on my preference. I also pur√©ed the onion, garlic, seasoning mixture before adding potatoes. It keeps the taste without the actual pieces of onion - a gamer changer if someone doesn‚Äôt really like onions. It also thickens and becomes creamy (because of the oil with it). And, I added the bacon at the very end. Delicious and excellent thickness/creaminess. Thanks!

text:
The key to making this revolves around the type of bacon used and how it is cooked. Be careful when cooking the bacon; if you allow the bacon to char it will overpower the flavor of everything else. Mine turned out really good; I didn't actually measure ingredients and used half and half though.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6262933.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make this soup all of the time but I absolutely never have cilantro (I hate it), or tarragon in my house. That said I obviously omit those. I also save time by cubing and cooking the potatoes first while you cook the bacon that way you only have to throw it together in the end instead of waiting for the potatoes to cook. It really doesn‚Äôt need a lot of seasoning with all that bacon in there (being a New Englander I often use maple flavored) but I do often throw in a couple shakes of Italian seasoning. The last step of throwing half of the soup into your food processor and blending it to then reintroduce it back into the soup is an absolutely crucial step to making this soup great. I always save a few crisp pieces of bacon to crumble on the top when serving.

country:
None
text:
I made this a few times... I simply used this as a base for my own potato soup. To start I used the ingredients that I had in my kitchen already so we used regular potatoes (peeled), leftover ham from the holidays, butter, celery, onions, heavy whipping cream, chicken stock and scallions for garnish.  We cooked ours in a crockpot, following most of the steps as directed. I used seasonings that I liked in my flavorful soups, like garlic and onion powder, along with my favorite chicken soup base we added in with some butter to the stock.  This soup was very delicious, I like mine a little bit chunky and thick, so I mashed some of the potatoes in the crockpot once they got soft enough to mash. Will continue to use this as a base for my own potato soup recipe.  Season to taste is key!

text:
I made this with lactaid whole milk and it was plenty rich and thick without the cream.  We have several with lactose intolerance.  The pot was "downed" quickly with several that were disappointed that it was gone already before they could get seconds.  Total hit!!! The tarragon really gives it a GREAT flavor.  I added cayenne for a "kick" since my family likes spicy.  I also used 1/4 cup all purpose gluten free flour and 1 Tablespoon of cornstarch since I have someone with celiac who ate some.  This soup was better than any you would get at Panera, even with the health changes.

text:
We did NOT like this soup at all, sorry.  The bacon was flabby, the flavor was off, and who on earth puts cilantro in potato soup???  Hey, if it‚Äôs your thing and you like it that way, by all means make it.  But I prefer simple potato soup with the vegetables cooked in bacon fat, milk, a roux, and chicken stock. Maybe fresh thyme if you have it.  But the crispy bacon was added only at the table, along with sharp cheddar and sour cream.   The flavors in this recipe were not compatible to my family at all, and it was oddly flat tasting, as if it were under seasoned under all that horrible cilantro.   I gave it 2 stars instead of 1 simply because I know some people love cilantro and add it to everything. But if you don‚Äôt enjoy that flavor, do not make this recipe, because it won‚Äôt work for you, even if you leave it out.  The soup was wan and bland .

city:

country:
None
text:
I usually try to try new recipes as stated, and modify them when I feel they are lacking something. So, I did make this recipe as stated other than using evaporated milk instead of cream since that's what I had on hand. I didn't put the bacon back into the soup, but saved it for garnish. I used an immersion blender to blend some of the potatoes and accidentally blended in too many. So the soup initially came out very thick. Since my husband was standing at the stove ready for the taste test, he and I both tasted it and agreed it was too bland. We also agreed that it was too thick, but that was my fault. Since I made this soup for tomorrow night's dinner, I left it on the stove while I figured out what to do with it. I initially used peeled red potatoes, but decided to microwave some yellow potatoes to dice and add to the soup. Then I added enough milk to thin it some, but still leave it creamy. I also added 2 tablespoons of chopped fresh basil. After these additions, we did another taste test. WOW, the taste was wonderful. Since I had not yet added anything that would add to the flavor, I am assuming that it has to sit for a little while for all of the flavors to meld and come through. I should also mention that I used homemade chicken broth and not store bought. When I serve it tomorrow evening, I plan to garnish it with the reserved bacon and green onions. I really don't think it needs much of anything else.

text:
This recipe is very flavorful and we enjoyed it tremendously. I kept the ingredients exactly as written but made it in my new crockpot, which has a saut√© feature. After returning the bacon to the pot and adding the broth, I turned it on 350 for 30 minutes. My family likes a smoother soup so after everything was cooked I blended it with an immersion blender. I think that was key, otherwise the bacon would have been chewy and kind of unappetizing. Blending it retained all the flavour that had cooked it. Wonderful!!

Display Name:
Madeline Graham

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2285165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first time making baked potato soup (I'm actually not much of a cook in general to be honest, but I'm trying to change that), and I must say, I hit a home run with this recipe! My husband (who is usually fairly critical) and my brother both said there's nothing they would have changed. One note that others have mentioned as well: This absolutely takes longer than  50 minutes. Took me about an hour and a half (and that was with some hustle and my husband helping a little bit). 

Notes on some changes I made: I mashed the soup instead of pureeing it (as one reviewer suggested), and the texture came out great (possibly better than a puree to be honest, since it was still thick and chunky). I also included some pre-cooked sausage when I threw in the garlic. This made the meal more substantive and added some great flavor. I also waited to put the cooked, chopped bacon in until the very end (instead of letting it boil with the potatoes). They stayed nice and crispy this way. I also tossed in some salt and extra tarragon. No cilantro.
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
Made it almost according to recipe except for:
   -  added cooked bacon to roux and took some soup broth to 
     thin cream sauce to accommodate
   -  used 1 tsp. fresh minced dill instead of coriander (cilantro)
   -  mashed instead of puree
   -  used 3 kinds of potatoes:  baking, boiling and fingerlings 
       w/purple potatoes
Served with fresh bread spread with garlic butter and Parmesan cheese, broiled.  FANTASTIC

text:
This is a great recipe! I didn‚Äôt add the cream/flour mixture since hubby is lactose intolerant. To save time I added a bag of frozen Idaho hash brown dices with carrots and celery and cooked in olive oil, then added ham dices instead of bacon. Costco chicken stock is very flavorful so I added that with one pod of Knoor chicken flavor pod and LOTs of pepper. I cooked it for about 40mins until some of the potatoes became mushy to thicken the broth. This was soooo good. A keeper for sure since the hubby enjoyed it so much. He asked for it in his lunch for work, something he rarely asks. Enjoy and thank you for the recipe

text:
It was fine, but not great. I really wish I had gone with a parsley/chive herb combo, instead of the tarragon/cilantro combo suggested here. Just my preference.

I prefer a more robust flavor. Next time I will add shallots and/or leeks instead of onions, and white pepper. I will DEFINITELY add the bacon as a topper, instead of cooking it with the soup. It is rubbery and soggy, not at all flavorful.  

I used my hand mixer to blend it up at the end. That helped thicken it up a little. I'd rather rely on cream and butter to thicken it up and enrich the flavor. I'll make it again, but with my modifications. My rating is based on the recipe as it's written.

text:
Delicious! I didn't use bacon; substituted olive oil in that first step.  I added a bit of salt, pepper, oregano & parsley to the onions, celery, & garlic mixture as they cooked. I also added fresh mushrooms that I chopped and sauteed with the cilantro & tarragon. The only seasonings I used were salt, pepper, & Goya Adobo. I skipped the puree step and instead mashed a bit of the potatoes as they cooked in the chicken stock. (I prefer the chunky potatoes for the stew instead of the puree texture.) For serving dinner, I added green peas and a pinch of shredded cheese to each bowl of soup. The whole family loved this one!

city:
