region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe many times, but I really use it as a guideline, since I am horrible at following directions. I add a lot more celery, onion, potato and also use ham and bacon.  I use whatever milk is on hand, 2% or whole milk and half and half.  I start by saut√©ing the bacon a bit, then add the onion and garlic, saut√© for a bit longer. I usually add a 5# bag of potatoes, or more, depending on who's coming for dinner, and cover with chicken broth to boil all ingredients at once. Then add butter and flour roue to thicken. Serve with chives or scallion, bacon crumbles and shredded cheddar cheese. Great Fall meal.

text:
I've made this soup probably 12-15 times now and it is by far the best potato based soup I've ever made/tried. It's perfect. The only thing I change is I cook the bacon in strips in a skillet then add some bacon grease to my Dutch oven to saut√© the veggies. I then chop the bacon and add it right before the cream mixture. That way the bacon holds some flavor. I constantly get requests for this recipe and I always give the credit to Allrecipes and it's  members!  Haha thanks OP!!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
When I made this the first time I found it quite bland.  I've made it a few times since and here are the changes:
1. I use a whole head of garlic
2. Add worchestershire sauce
3.  Add cayenne pepper for a kick
4. I cook the bacon in the same pot I make the soup in that way I get all the bits from the bacon for more flavor.
5.  When I thicken the cream (I use 18% cream) I just use leftover bacon fat instead of butter.
6.  I don't boil the bacon.  I add it back in after I puree the soup.

country:
None
text:
Okay, okay, gotta chime in here. Made an account just to post. This soup is absolutely fantastic BUT!! (It's a big but), I do not recommend add the fatty bacon back in to simmer with the potatoes. Just don't. If you're going to do it that way, make sure it's only meat and not fat as the fat turns back into, well, fat, and doesn't stay crispy. I mean, I should have known it would do it, but with two kids at my feet, I just wasn't thinking.

So please, if you make this, only place the crispy meat parts and not the crispy fat back in to simmer with potatoes.

Otherwise, I kind of winged it. It turned out fantastic. Is a great starter to add on your own. Would definitely make it again.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2017-02-03T23:36:59.807
helpfulCount:

city:

country:

text:
I have been using all recipes for quite some time and this is the FIRST TIME that I have chosen to do a review... I love to cook and I find that this site usually has the best recipes and the best reviewer comments... So, I decided that I needed to start giving back ...:)

I read about 40 reviews of this soup and so, I was prepared that it might taste TOO BLAND at the end...The only substitution that I made in the beginning was that I chose to use RED POTATOES instead of the russet potatoes... That was a personal choice and only because I prefer the buttery taste of red potatoes... Since, I was using a 5 quart cast iron skillet I needed about 16 red potatoes instead of the 8 russet ones...

I know a lot of the readers were concerned about the cilantro but it is VERY MILD... In all honesty I probably would have doubled or tripled the amount that was suggested but I am from San Antonio, TX and I love cilantro in almost everything...

This recipe does get VERY THICK so, I added an additional cup of 2 % milk in order to give it more of a soupy consistency...

As one reviewer said "This is a GREAT BASE RECIPE"... but it is far too bland... Like Crystal S. I added additional ingredients:

 2 tsp white pepper, 2 leeks saut√©ed in butter and salt, 1 tsp of Cayenne Pepper, an additional 1 tsp of tarragon and a tablespoon of parsley flakes towards the end and it was absolutely DELICIOUS!! 

I did not add the bacon pieces until  the last 45 min so as to avoid the bacon becoming soggy...

text:
I decided on this recipe after taking stock of what was in my fridge that needed to be used up - bacon, caramelized onions, chicken broth, cilantro, cream, and a bag of potatoes. I can't place the taste of tarragon, nor did I have any, so didn't include it. I also don't like celery in soups so did not include that either. The caramelized onions were what made the soup though. They'd spent more than an hour on slow heat and added a distinct but delicious flavor. The cilantro was great also. I never would have thought to include it in potato soup. I'm looking forward to the leftovers tonight as the flavors have probably  matured after being chilled for a day. I'm adding this recipe to my favorites.

text:
Great base recipe. This was my 1st time not only making but eating Potato Soup. I make potatoes of some sort a minimum of 3 times a week so playing w/ the flavor and spices in this recipe was second nature. I didn't really use measurements and just kinda added what felt was right. I also waited until about the last 2-3 min of cook time (after the puree step) added a good bit of diced (1/2-3/4 inch square) leftover Thanksgiving ham along  w/ the bacon. If you add bacon earlier it will have the taste & texture of boiled bacon. YUCK! Very pleased w/ this recipe, I will be adding it to my online box & my family keepsake handwritten box.

text:
This recipe has become a family favorite.  I started making it several years ago on holidays, and now it has become a regular part of our dinner menu options.  One tip I might add: If your soup is not as thick as you like, add a small amount of instant mashed potatoes to help thicken.  I found that I can lessen the flour I used in the roux and make up the thickening with the instant potatoes.

d perey

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5655009.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good basic potato soup with plenty of bacon flavor.  
The key is the quality of bacon - the more smoked bacon flavor, the better your soup will be.

I used Yukon Gold potatoes -very rich and smooth.

The heavy cream is the key ingredient and making a roux to thicken it is important.  

Another review stated a little complicated, but its pretty easy other than making the roux.  

Kids gobbled it up.  I didn't have cilantro, but that didn't matter.

The cream makes it pretty rich, so I think you could substitute whole milk and that would still make a great soup - just not as rich.  maybe a little less thick.

Adding sausage or some kielbasa would make this very harty.

text:
This soup is fabulous, delicious and lip smacking good!  I have never been a potato soup lover -- until I made this. The only change I made was using an immersion blender on the whole pot -- as opposed to half of it, but that's just personal preference.  I love the richness of this but want to cut back on some of the fat. So today I'll make it using half and half instead of cream and see how that works. But whatever, this soup is a favorite in my house and there's never a drop left!  Thanks so much for sharing this recipe!!!

The ULTIMATE comfort food. I added extra broth because it was a bit thick for me, but the flavor was beyond amazing. My Colombian husband called this "gringo ajiaco", which is a really high compliment. This soup definitely generates that same comforting feeling. We will definitely be adding this to our regular rotation.  :)

userID:
20701761
Display Name:
Ivette Marie
isPro:

followersCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674147.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I didn't have any bacon or celery on hand so I cooked the onion, garlic and subbed chopped green onion for celery in a little oil. After adding the potatoes and chicken broth I knew I needed extra seasoning to make up for the lack of bacon grease so I threw in salt, pepper and two big spoons of chicken bouillon. Then came the problem- when I tried to melt my butter and whisk in the flour I found it very difficult. It formed giant clumps then made a dough. This dough was delicious but bad for soup so I added in the heavy cream (used about an extra cup), cooked it for a couple mins with the clumpy dough and threw it in my blender. I think I added the flour too quickly, not sure but my blender solved that problem. I poured the creamy mixture into the pan and cooked it some more before combining it with my potatoes then I did puree half the soup like the recipe calls for.  At the end I cooked up some sliced sausage and added that in before serving as well as some fresh parsley on top. The consistency would have been too liquidy without my extra cup of heavy cream... The melted butter and flour mixing ended up terribly. So I would say the recipe was just okay.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5216734.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is almost perfect as is. I love the cream instead of milk. The only change I made was I substituted marjoram for the tarragon just b/c I didn't have any on hand. I also minced 6 cloves of garlic rather than 3. I don't care what the others said about skipping pureeing half the soup. Absolutely do that! If you throw it in the blender there isn't much mess, totally worth the extra dish to wash. It gives the soup better flavor and makes it more creamy. I grew up on creamy potato soup and I don't like it any other way. I did add about 2 teaspoons of salt, to me potato soup should be salty. As others said be aware start to finish time is assuming your vegetables are already chopped. Plan on about 2 hours from start to finish. Add some shredded cheese to your bowl of soup to serve! Thanks for this recipe it will definitely be in my winter time rotation!

text:
Don't be shy with the bacon: Worth getting the good brand--and using half or all of the package; the key to getting that smoky flavor is in using the bacon grease!!  Don't worry about  thickness either; this recipe takes care of that.  Add all your favorite baked potato fixings with each bowl you'll enjoy; makes a great cool / cold weather soup!!

text:
Dynamic recipe. I followed the recipe almost as written and also added about a quarter cup of Leaks with a small onion. I used bacon instead of butter to saute the vegetables and did not add carrots or tarragon. I saved some  bacon to sprinkle on top of the soup on the finished product. Thank you for all your posts... They're so helpful especially when deciding whether to use broth or chicken stock. It does make a difference. I used chicken stock , it makes it so much more flavorful. I think the bacon and the butter makes it salty enough so I didn't add any salt, and seasoned it with cayenne pepper. Thanks for the recipe Karena.

After my potatoes were tender I mashed them with a hand held mixed to make them nice and smooth.I also used cheese in my rue sauce which made a creamy cheese flavor . text:
Wonderful! Tasted even better the next day. The few changes I made were based on my taste and what I had available. I baked some broccoli in the oven until crispy, chopped it and added it towards the end of letting it simmer. I also added some fresh rosemary along with the cilantro. Put a few shakes of red pepper flakes as well. I like my potato soup chunky so I only blended 1/3. It really had a wonderful taste. I garnished with paprika, fresh parsley and a generous portion of sharp cheddar. Thanks for the recipe. Definitely will make again!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3586434.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Just finished making this yummy soup. I'm allowing it to cool and will reheat it later for dinner, which I'm sure will make it only better. I saved 1/2 the bacon out to use for topping, I'll also top with a little shredded cheddar and sliced green onions.  I did have to add a little more liquid - chicken stock and a little cream. I used almost double the amount of tarragon as well. I would note that it would be nice to have more of a guide to the amount of potatoes than just '8 potatoes' - what kind of potatoes? It would be better to give a number of pounds since potato sizes vary so much. Also, 3 teaspoons is equal to 1 Tablespoon, makes it a whole lot less of a hassle to measure out the freshly chopped cilantro. :D I'm surprised at the people that said this was a lot of work. From beginning to end it took me 1 hour and 5 minutes. Maybe because I love to cook? To me that is a quick meal. Will make again. Thanks for the recipe.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I always like to try recipes in the exact form they are presented in, otherwise it seems unfair to rate it.  This recipe is delicious, the only change I made was to add the bacon back in last (because I didn't want it to get soggy or lose flavor) and I didn't puree, but mashed some of the potatoes as others have suggested (because I don't have a food processor).  My only suggestion is don't forget the "salt and pepper to taste" part of the recipe.  After reading all these reviews, I was expecting to be blown away when I first tasted it.  But instead it was extremely bland - but once I added a teaspoon of salt and a 1/4 teaspoon black pepper to the pot and blended well - it was perfect for my tastes.

I read in some reviews that some thought it tastes like soap and that is totally how it smelled like to me just on my hands from handling it. I used less than 1 tablespoon to be on the safe side and I still couldn't eat it.  I was wary of using the cilantro but I read so many good reviews that I thought I would try the full recipe first before I made any hasty decisions.  Too bad I didn't go with my gut instinct, this was not a cheap recipe to make, don't even talk about my time. I am still willing to try the recipe again and tweak it to my personal taste. I most likely will not try the recipe again with the tarragon either.  Maybe I'm just a plain Jane......

This was a nice base, but needed tweaking. I added a few chopped carrots to the saut√©  of celery and onion. I also added a generous tsp. of salt when I added the potato to the pot. I did not have any cream, so I used 2 TBS of butter and 3 TBS of flour to make a roux, with about 3/4 cup of whole milk (I was making only 4 servings). After adding this to the potato mixture, I added about 1/2 cup of a grated Italian blend cheese. I'll definitely make again!

Great soup. I did not need to pur√©e this. Also, I needed to add more liquid at the end. And most importantly, the instruction to season to taste is extremely important here. This is especially true if you need this to be a vegetarian option because you lose all of that bacon flavour.

text:
This was super yummy. My potatoes were huge, and I like the soup extra creamy so I doubled the roux. We also don't like onions, so I doubled the garlic, and we had no celery so I used celery seeds. I added 25% more bacon fat, and replaced 25% of the heavy cream with milk. It came out delicious. I didn't have to put the potatoes in a blender. I cooked them in the pan as called for and then boiled them on medium heat until they were tender. Talk about creamy goodness and comfort food. Perfect for a snowy winter's day.

text:
This soup was very good, especially with a bit of shredded cheddar sprinkled on top. There was no need to puree half of the soup as it was already very creamy and the potatoes were falling apart.  The only change I would make is to use half or even a third of the bacon. I really wanted to taste the potatoes and there was too much bacon in each spoonful for my liking. The bacon also made the soup a bit too salty so there was definitely no need to add more.

This is my go to recipe for potato soup. My family loves it. I always add carrots and sometimes diced ham or frozen corn just to change things up once in awhile. The soup was definitely quite tasty.  I did make a few adjustments though.  I used gluten-free flour instead of regular flour, half n half milk, and added in a few additional cloves of garlic because I like garlic.  I did notice that the soup came out extremely thick and creamy for my taste, so I will probably eliminate the flour altogether and maybe use regular whole milk next time.

country:
None
text:
So good. Very thick, hearty soup. I took a lot of tips from other reviewers making it 5 stars after alterations.
-Add the bacon at the end
-Add shredded cheese at the end
-Do puree or hand mash a couple times

I also didn't add tarragon or cilantro. I didn't have any on hand. Tastes fantastic without. Be very careful with the cream mixture over heat so it doesn't separate. Just get it warm enough to melt, mix, and thicken. And my husband wished for some scallions to be added.

text:
i made this soup today and it was a hit with my soup picky husband. i followed the recipe with just a few changes as i wanted to make it using what i had on hand, so instead of the 1/2&1/2 cream i used 2% milk and to boost the flavour i added 1 tbsp of sour cream, this in my opinion made it a bit too rich so note to self use only the milk. i  used parsley instead of the cilantro and used (Better than Bouillon chicken base) instead of chicken stock.. i  feel that 1 lb of bacon was a bit much so next time i will only use 2/3rds lb. for colour and nutrition i added 1 cup frozen peas. will definitely make this again!

text:
I made this and a bacon, leek and potato soup at the same time.  So far, this one is my favorite between the two.  

I took a few liberties with the recipe, such as using replacing the butter line with an approximately 50/50 mix of butter and chilled bacon drippings.  I used a stick blender to blend the entire mixture instead of the 50% that the recipe called for.  I also used a combination of red potatoes and russet potatoes while making this; using 2 red potatoes are approximately 1 russet as a rough conversion factor. 

I think the cream+rue step is a strong part of what makes this recipe so darn yummy.

text:
Please take the time to read reviews!! If I had not I wouldn't have known the difference between, 'stock', and 'broth'. This soup is amazing!! My family could not stop eating it!
I don't leave low ratings on recipes due to the fact that there is the chance that it was me that did something wrong! I cook so much and have repeatedly used broth and ended up disappointed with flavorless results. 
For the stock I used a combo of beef, pork, and roasted chicken bones. I threw in some carrots, onions, and celery and let it simmer for about 5 hrs. That on its own tasted amazing!
Like another reviewer said, I too added leeks. For the bacon I chose apple smoked. It was delicious :-)

Display Name:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious! Made this soup last night (and will make again, and again). ***3 Alterations: I used 5 large peeled russet potatoes instead of the red, as it was all I had in the house. And I added 2 large unpeeled chopped carrots. I also did not use blender to puree but used potato masher a few seconds to do the job. Less mess. Also, a word about using the Dutch Oven (I have a La Creuset): when cooking up the bacon, the bottom of the pan will get some heavy browning. THIS IS GOOD and expected. When the veggies go in, that will lift off and add TONS of bacon flavoring. CHANGES FOR NEXT TIME: I'll most likely not use heavy cream; maybe half-n-half or whole milk or maybe no milk at all! Lastly: make sure you use chicken STOCK NOT BROTH!!! Broth has much less flavor and depth.

text:
This is pretty good. I made 4 servings so reduced the recipe to 3 strips of bacons, 5 potatoes and substituted heavy cream with sour cream (1/2 cup) and a pinch of ground oregano in lieu of cilantro. I accidentally added 1/2 and not 1/4 cup of flour which made the cream balled up and chunky. I mitigated this problem by putting it through the blender which rendered it a nice, creamy texture. The soup turned out beautifully.

text:
As written, I'm giving this 3 stars. It is a great base recipe, but very bland as written.  After 5 of us sampled the soup, we agreed that it definitely needed more flavor. I added a lot of garlic,  some garlic salt, some kosher salt, black pepper, and an extra 1/2 onion and 4 more stalks of celery.  I also added extra tarragon and cilantro. Basically, I just kept taste testing until I felt the flavor fit my family!  After the adjustments made, my son told me "this soup is just TOO good!"

text:
Just amazing! So rich and creamy. Hands down the best potato soup I've had. Substitutions made to avoid a trip to the store: .6 lbs of Bacon (all I had left), 1 tsp of Italian Seasoning in place of Tarragon, Celery salt in place of Celery, Half and Half instead of Cream, 3 lbs of red potatoes. Not having made this before I can't say for certain, but it definitely didn't seem to suffer for the alterations. These changes dropped the calorie count to ~ 450 / 10 oz serving (80 oz total). Start to finish was 90 minutes for my first time (including clean up).

text:
I followed the recipe exactly except used turkey bacon and leek because that's what I had on hand.  This turns out a very thick soup which we liked on a cold and windy day, but you could easily add some milk to thin it if you want.  I thought the seasonings were perfect but I think it largely has to do with what kind of chicken broth you are using (I use a jarred paste).  The tarragon and cilantro combination really made this soup! Would love to try adding broccoli and/or cauliflower next time and maybe some cheese at the end.  Lots of possibilities with this one!

Display Name:

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I mad a few changes to my personal liking. After reading reviews I opted out on the flour rue and celery because my husband doesn't like celery. I tossed the potatoes in the bacon grease, bacon, onion and garlic then separated the potatoes half I kept in the pan cooked with chicken stock and pur√©ed when soft. I used that as my "rue" then combined with the cubed potatoes. 
I diced Mozerrella with Artichoke & Garlic Sausage and  apple & Gouda cheese sausage really small and added that to the soup along with chopped bacon. Before serving I added some shredded cheese to the soup itself. 
The only additional spices I added was white pepper  and cayenne.  Topped with bacon, cheese and green onion. 
My version is definitely not for those counting calories but boy was it scrumptious. Served with French and Sourdough bread. 
Great recipe to do so many yummy things with.

5

text:
This turned out really well...not a dropped left.  I did two things different...I used my SLOW COOKER so that we could have hot soup after a chilly softball practice after school...and this fit the bill.  I did step 2 and put it all in a slow cooker on low for 5 hours.  Instead of using bacon that I needed to pan fry, I bought  Hormel Black Label Bacon Bits...I would not use anything else as a substitute and added 1/2 the little jar to the soup.  After softball I whipped step 3 up on the stove and put it in the slow cooker and let simmer for 10 minutes.  As another  reader suggested I just used my masher and mashed it about 5 times and it turned out perfect.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674164.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Took longer cook time than expected but excellent recipe.  I sliced the potatoes into halves or quarters and microwaved them for a few minutes to reduce the cook time.  I added a little minced poblano pepper at the same time as the onion to add more flavor, but couldn't taste it  (next time will add more), and some parsley with the cilantro.  The cream mixture took a long to to thicken with a hand whisk.  Used an immersion blender instead of a blender to puree (left in some chunky bits), and ending up adding some extra chicken stock because it was so thick.  Served it with sweet sausage.   My son adding more garlic, some sour cream and cheese to his to give it a "loaded baked potato" flavor.  I ate mine straight.  It was yummy both ways.   This recipe is a keeper.
Review:

text:
Not sure what recipe Crystal followed but this soup is to die for!!!!!  I did add a little sour creme and about 1 cup of shredded cheddar cheese at the end of the cooking time.  I also did the cooking in a crock pot.  It saved me a lot of precious time as almost all of the ingredients were put in the crock at the beginning of prep.  The potatoes did not even need to be mashed/pureed.  I made not one but two crock pots of this soup for my Super Bowl party and didn't even get to keep a bowl for myself as the guests took it all home with them.

text:
When hubby says "it's a keeper" then I know I have found something really good! The video really helped, as well as the reviews, which I always read. And when I read MaggieOK2's review who stated: "The puree step near the end is very important. It highly affected the texture and flavor of the soup. Don't skip that step!" I made sure I did this step and she is right! I didn't have tarragon, so used Dill per the video and added salt and pepper to taste. It has a great smokey flavor to it thanks to the bacon. I normally make a potato cream cheese soup, but this may skip past it! As with all recipes, you can always season to taste!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
I dearly love potato soup! The changes I would make to this soup would be to add a lot more celery and onion. You can't put too much celery or onion into potato soup! I'd leave out the tarragon and cilantro, it's not needed. At the end, melt in a cup or two of your favorite shredded cheese. Instead of a cup of heavy cream, add a quart of half and half.  I use instant potatoes to thicken the soup and leave out the step for making a thickening. Throw in the crispy bacon last for a delicious crunch and you have a potato soup straight from heaven!

Just made this soup, and its a hit! My husband said "you had me at the name", and it really lives up to it. I "lightened" it a bit by not using the full pound of bacon, and leaving very little bacon grease in the pan to saut√© the onions and celery, and using milk instead of cream at the then, but it was still awesome! Its the first time I have ever had potato soup that I liked. We are going to try it next time by adding some shrimp, it has a great chowder flavor. Also used chives instead of cilantro because that was what I had fresh in the garden, and it was dee-lish!

text:
Just finished my first pot of this recipe, following it exactly as written, although have not pur√©ed the half of  it yet, and may not since the cream addition made the broth thick and substantial.  Husband, a real potato lover said it was "good, not great."  I liked it about 4 stars worth, and averaged the two ratings to 3 stars .  Because of the very high fat content, may not make it more than once a year, however!  Probably the fattiest, richest, soup I've ever made, but nice balance of flavors within it.  Do not feel it needs cheese as a topping, but maybe a few scallions to "pretty" it up.

text:
Loved the recipe, switched a few things up. I used 1/2 tsp of thyme and 1/2 oregano instead of majorum. Also added a 1/2cup of white wine while simmering with chicken stock, also added 4 drops of liquid smoke to the mix. Skipped the cilantro. After I bowled the soup up, I put 2 tbs shredded cheddar, 1 tbs green onion, and 1 tbs crumbled bacon, and a small drizzle of hot sauce on top. Awesome! Make sure to crumble the bacon before you toss it with the cooking potatoes.

text:
I thought like another commentor that it lacked flavor.  I omitted the terragan, cilantro and garlic because it just didn't sound good in potato soup.  However, I added a lb. of carrots, corn, a can of beer and more potatoes than the recipe called for along with salt and pepper.  I added just a little bit bacon grease to the pot from my baking sheet for health reasons.  I saut√©ed my onion and celery in a bit of olive oil.  I also had to add a lot of thickener at the end.  I did not puree but just mashed everything in the pot a couple of times.  I also did not want mushy bacon in my soup - yuck.  I baked my bacon and set it aside for crumbles on top along with shredded cheddar colby jack cheese and fresh parsley to dress it up in the bowl.  The family liked it.

I made this recipe for Mother's Day for the first time, and it was a hit! I followed the recipe exactly, and it was perfect. Make sure and add enough salt and pepper to it, as it will taste a bit bland if not added. People in my family who usually do not like soup loved it, which was a big deal! This soup goes perfectly with homemade rolls, like the "quick yeast rolls" which I made to go with it! I would recommend this recipe to anyone, cold or hot weather!

text:
First I read all of the reviews. Instead of onion I used a Leek.(first time I ever used one) I used chicken broth but I did add 2 packets of Swanson Chicken Flavor Boost. I used parsley instead of cilantro and tarragon. I did feel this could use a little more flavor (that's why I only gave it 4 stars) so I'm wondering if the tarragon and cilantro would have been good in the mixture. I crumbled up the bacon right before serving and put into the soup. I left some reserve for topping the soup in our bowls plus I sprinkled shredded cheese and sliced green onion, so good! The green onion gave it a little more flavor. I did not puree it, I didn't feel it needed it. My 11 yr old only added more crumbled bacon to the top of his and he LOVED it! He's very picky. He's the reason I made this soup, he loves potato soup! I will definitely make this again.

text:
I used 6 potatoes, 1 onion,3 cloves of garlic, 1/2 package of bacon, 3 packets of chicken bouillon, 1 cup of milk, 3 large spoons of butter and flour
dice and brown bacon, strain all grease, fry onion then garlic, then add potatoes, bouillon w/ 4 cups of water and boil for about 15 min
 in separate pot, milt butter, add flour, whisk in flour, add to cooked soup.

text:
I combined this with several other potato soup recipes and made it my own, but this was the best one I found and the recipe I followed most closely. I didn't have that much bacon and I had no celery, but I added some green peppers finely chopped which did help. I substituted half milk half/sour cream for heavy cream and it turned out well. I let it simmer and reduce a bit until it got to desired thickness. I still found it to be a bit brothy, so I slightly mashed it with a potato masher. This really helped thicken it up and add to the creaminess! Very good!

text:
This soup turned out delicious! I had to make two modifications based on what I had on hand. I didn't have any bacon so I used a 1/4 cup butter in place of the bacon grease. I only had skim milk so I used that instead of heavy cream. I was fully prepared to add some sour cream in at the end for some extra creaminess but it really didn't need it so I didn't. I loved the flavor of the tarragon in this soup. If it's this delicious without bacon and heavy cream I know it's gotta be amazing with them, so next time I will make this exactly as written for a treat. Thanks for this great recipe.

userID:
6823581
Display Name:
Jordan L
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5185980.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really liked this recipe and it makes for a great starter that allows you to experiment a little. I used basil instead of tarragon, which I really liked and I also added green onions and fresh shredded pepper jack cheese at the end. The green onion did a little bit for presentation, but I liked the pepper jack cheese, because a there were a few bites that would have a little kick. I also added cooked bacon before adding the cream mixture and some more after adding the cream mixture. I would recommend adding it at the end, because the bacon doesn't have as much flavor after sitting in with everything else for so long.

I also did not use a blender, because i don't have one, so I just mashed them with a spatula (also don't have a potato masher) and though the potatoes weren't mashed entirely, I got the texture that I wanted. I don't see any need to add salt because I used chicken broth. Overall, was really pleased with this recipe and will definitely be making this again.

Display Name:
GenaH.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this tonight, really good soup.  I didn't change one ingredient other than using my own homemade **chicken stock.  I cooked it longer than it says because I think longer cooking develops more flavor.  Half an hour before I was ready to serve I added the *butter/flour/cream mixture and half of the bacon.  I reserved the rest for garnish.

*I used light cream that I use for my coffee.  The grocery store was completely out of heavy cream.  Turned out fine.  Half & Half would probably work as well.

**I use Ina Garten's recipe for chicken stock but I do not use 3 whole chickens.  I use chicken backs and necks that equal about 3 lbs and any remaining bones from roasting, rotisserie etc, (just toss bones in a ziplock bag and freeze them until you're ready for stock day!)  It's amazing and yields about 6 quarts of stock.  I use it regularly and I'll never buy store bought chicken "broth" again.

I made this soup with a few changes. I used garlic powder instead, left out the cilantro and tarragon, mainly because I didn't have any ;) using parsley, celery seed and salt/pepper was a plus. There were only 5 stars or I would have rated this higher!!

text:
I thought the recipe was amazing but I did not follow it exactly. I did my own thing. I sauteed the onion, celery and garlic in virgin olive oil and 2tsp of butter. I used four large sweet potatoes instead. I used vegetable broth and added one teaspoon of chicken bouillon for flavor. I made my own heavy cream (1/3 cup of butter melted and I added 3/4cup of soymilk to it). I didn't have and tarragon so I looked up a substitute and found that I could use marjoram instead since I had that on hand. Lastly since I am a vegetarian I used vegetarian backon bits and stirred them into the soup instead of the actual bacon. Sounds like a lot but everything was done in the 40mins like the original recipe. My husband and 13 month old loved it. Oh and we topped our bowls with some shredded cheddar cheese. AMAZING!

text:
This recipe was great. I did however lack quite a few of the ingredients so I made quite a few substitutes that worked out great! In the second step I used skim milk with a dollop of sour cream and about 1/8 C of grated Romano cheese (for extra flavor boost). I also only had chicken broth so I added about 2 Tbs of chicken bullion to give it a richer flavor. Basil replaced the tarragon and of course plenty of salt and pepper added in slowly between the different steps. Even with all that it turned out great and my picky 8 year old ate it up! Will definitely save this recipe and make it again!

text:
My family absolutely loved it!!!  Made my own modifications.   Did not add tarragon & cilantro.  Chopped bacon then cooked till crisp.  Added bacon back at the end.  Used half & half instead of cream but will try milk next time as it was very thick.  Did not puree 1/2, just mashed the potatoes with my wisk.  Added sharp cheddar cheese at the end.  This recipe is so good, restaurant quality!!  The flavors of the bacon, cheese & green onion garnish gave it a loaded baked potato flavor.  My 11 yr old had a cooking lesson & prepared this with me.

text:
Thank you for sharing this recipe! It was absolutely delicious! I did lighten it up so it wouldn't be quite as fattening, and it was still very delicious! I used turkey bacon instead of regular bacon. It was a lot less fatty, but I had to add oil to the pot because there wasn't enough oil for sauteing the veggies because turkey bacon is so much less fatty. I also just used milk instead of using cream. It thickens up very nicely. Though I'm wondering just how wonderful it tastes when cream is used. I'll have to try that on a special occasion. :) I also ground up about 1 tsp of fennel seeds rather than using tarragon. I haven't used it before so I'm not really sure about the taste. I'll have to try it sometime! This recipe was delicious! Thanks for sharing!

I made this soup as stated and was sure to use chicken stock and not broth.  I did add about one teaspoon of seasoned salt at the very end and it was FANTASTIC.  Thick and very filling. You can make it as thick or as thin as you like by blending more or less of the soup.  As good as it was, next time I'll probably add a bay leaf while the potatoes are cooking and use less bacon.  Time consuming?  Yes, but oh so worth it!

text:
Eh. This was just so-so. After reading all of the positive reviews (and as the title implies), I thought I was going to be in for a real treat. To my surprise, this was super BLAND! Even my hubs commented what a shame it was to indulge when there are better (and more satisfying) options out there to justify the splurge. :( NOTE: This makes a VERY large pot of soup! We enjoy leftovers during the hectic work week, so I made the full 8 servings worth. Unfortunately, we didn't care for this soup enough to make a second meal of it, so my parents were the happy recipients of our leftovers. :) Maybe this will become your go-to potato soup recipe, but it won't be mine. If you enjoy potato soup, Ellie's ham & potato soup seems to be the winner on here (and is a 5 star recipe in my book). Thanks anyways, Karena.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674164.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe today.  It is a great recipe.  Keep one thing in mind when preparing this recipe....the one teaspoon of tarragon does come through in this recipe.  If you like this spice you are all set, but if you do not leave this spice out, or decrease the amount.  Next time I make this recipe I will probably add 1/4 teaspoon of tarragon.  Also, we prefer a soup that is not so thick...I ended up adding 3 tablespoons of flour to the butter and it thickened the liquid part of the recipe perfectly.  I used 24 ounces of chicken broth...that is all it took to cover my potatoes.  When preparing this recipe the aromas were wonderful.  I enjoy using Allrecipes when preparing meals.

YUMMY! My family are not big soup eaters (I am) so I thought I would enjoy this for days but the pot is all gone! They enjoyed it, even my picky 13 yr old. I didn't have heavy cream so I made it with 3/4 milk and 3 tbs melted, cooled butter. I also didn't have tarragon but I added a garlic and onion powder, white pepper and parsley flakes instead. I didn't have fresh cilantro, only dry so I used that too. This recipe is a sure fire keeper.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614260.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had to make a couple of omissions since I didn't have all the ingredients on hand (and I really wanted potato soup!). I did not add the cilantro or the tarragon and the taste was still a very good potato soup taste. I used half and half instead of heavy cream and glad I did as the texture was so thick, it was more like a big bowl of chunky mashed potatoes rather than a "soup", and I did not even puree any of the soup. I still very much enjoyed this soup and it was very filling. I may try next time to cook the potatoes less time (so they don't fall apart as easily creating a mashed consistency) and I probably will add more chicken broth and maybe a handful of shredded cheddar. Overall, I did like it and will make it again with these minor adjustments.

text:
Wonderful recipe for a cold night, served with stone baked bread.  I will modify a few things next time though. 1. Cut back on bacon grease as others have stated & sub another kind of oil if needed to cook onion in(olive or canola) to cut back on fat content, also a little too much bacon favor taking away from potato flavor.  2. Had to add more stock/milk to make thinner b/c it was really thick as written. Made full recipe and froze 1/2 so hopefully freezing works. Will definitely make again. Thanks for the wonderful recipe!

text:
This recipe is excellent, though I did make a few changes.  To cut down on some calories and saturated fat, I used a 12 oz can of fat free evaporated milk instead of heavy cream.   I also used 6 potatoes instead of 8 and 4 tbsp of butter instead of 3. I also used a12oz package of peppered bacon instead of a lb of regular bacon to add some more flavor.  It really turned out great, I will absolutely make it again with these same changes.  I love how there is no cheese but its still creamy and delicious! 5 stars for sure!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As written, this soup is lacking and is very heavy. I added at least a cup, likely more, of white wine with the chicken broth, several tablespoons of Chicken Flavored Better than Bouillon, garlic powder, lots of white pepper, salt & freshly cracked black pepper. I also added Asiago cheese to the roux. This recipe takes a good long time to make, much more than the poster says, once you brown the bacon, cut all the ingredients, etc. I'm letting the soup sit until the potatoes break down on their own. The flavor is good now, but definitely had to doctor it up!

text:
The only modification I made to this recipe was a dash of salt in the food processor (well, more like a few teaspoons), and some parmesan cheese to the top.  Also, the recipe needs to specify the size of potato. Are we talking 8 LARGE russet potatoes? I bought 8, and quickly realized I need use only 4. Unlike many recipes out there, this one didn't turn into mushy soup. I didn't have to add a ton of flour to get the right consistency. I'm very pleased! I will be using this again. And again. And perhaps again!

Very good, however, I have to disagree with ever adding a flour base to a starchy soup.  To thicken this soup just puree a portion of your potatoes and add back into the soup.  You can always add an extra potato or two for this step. You can still add your cream and butter for richness if you want.

This is the soup my mother made so many times during WW2, but without the bacon.  I don't know if she made it with cream or milk.  She learned from her mother during the depression. Tastey! I however used evaporated milk because I didnt have heavy cream.  I used the whole 14oz can because people said it was very thick, but it still turned out very thick which is what I wanted anyways.  Didn't use cilantro.  Used only 1/2 lb of bacon and cooked for a total of 3 hrs on low :) Used a potato masher to act as if blending, was easier. I will be using this recipe over and over again.  Thanks!

text:
This recipe turned out quite bland for me. I added some cayenne pepper and some cheese, and that helped, but this recipe is not one I will make again.  Also, you may want to add more chicken stock when you are cooking it as mine turned out quite thick.  One thought to anyone who might be looking for a baked potato soup--this isn't it (and never claims to be), but I thought I would point out that the flavors are quite distinct.

text:
This was wonderful! I have not had much luck with potato soups, but this one turned out just the way I like it. I made some substitutions, to reduce the fat content. I used turkey bacon and hallf & half instead of heavy cream. This was time consuming to prepare but well worth it. The prep time is listed as 10 minutes and the cook time is listed as 30. No way, I would say I spent closer to two hours. Next time I'll probably double up on the garlic and herbs, just for my own personal taste prefrences.

Amazing,creamy,rich with a touch of smokey flavor from the bacon.  I used 1/2 & 1/2 in place of cream, and added celery seed and chives instead of cilantro and tarragon only because I don't have them.  If you don't puree 1/2 the soup, you're missing the extra creaminess this provides.  Great comfort soup!  Thank you for the recipe.

text:
This recipe was really good, however I did make some minor changes that I felt were more healthy. I used turkey bacon as well as half and half instead of whole cream, and some colby jack cheese. I think that next time I will totally omit the bacon from the recipe because after cooking the bacon and then putting it back into the soup it became soggy again, and I am not a big fan of the texture of soggy bacon. Next time I will add some broccoli, it was a good recipe and it will be made again. I served this with the chedder bay biscuits and everyone had seconds.

text:
This was an amazing recipe.  I could not get enough of it.  I modified the recipe a bit.  I decided not to use the 1 lb of bacon and used butter instead of bacon grease.  I did eventually add bacon, some of that pre-cooked stuff.  That was actually a good move.  I added some vegetable oil after I put in the potatoes and that seemed to work well.  I did not have enough butter for the flour and cream mixture so I used margarine in place of it.  It ended up fine.  This recipe is open to so many spices so just have fun with it and go with your instincts.  Cheese goes well with it as well.  :)

I made this tonight and it was great. My husband complimented me several times. I used canned chicken broth with some boullion cubes to make it more flavorful.  I also added about a cup of shredded cheddar cheese to the cream sauce til it blended well.  I added more cream to it a little at a time.  It was so fulling.  Perfect fall meal.  I would have to say that the time is inaccurate though. From start to finish incl cooking the bacon it was about 90 mins

This is a bit time consuming but very tasty.  I made the recipe exactly except I didn't have any heavy cream and used fat free half-and-half instead.  It still thickened up nicely and didn't affect the taste at all.  I used a hand held immersion blender and 3 quick pulses and the soup was almost pure√©d more than I wanted.  Be careful to not over process - soup was not as chunky as I intended it to be.

text:
OK, am I the only one that felt like I was eating a bowl of gravy?  WAY TOO GLUTENOUS for us.  Although it was tasty, it was too thick, even though I "watered" it down with twice the amount of half and half (recipe calls for heavy cream, though)  I used only five pieces of bacon and that was plenty.  I gave it three stars because I would probably make this again, but with a revision.  Leave out or reduce the flour, so it does not have such a pasty consistancy. The recipe says to puree half of the soup, next time I wouldn't take as much out...we like it a little more chunky.  Good luck on this one...Hope you're not on a diet.

text:
This soup is absolutely delicious. It is so hearty and has such a wonderful flavor.  I did however do a few things different.  When I cut my bacon up, I threw away the ends that had all of the fat.  So when I fried up the bacon, there wasn't that much grease.  So I drizzled a little olive oil on the celery and onions and it was fine.  I also left out the tarragon and cilantro beacause I didn't have any and it still tasted great.  I don't think that I will add it next time either.  I think it will cover up that great bacon flavor.  Thank you Karena for a great recipe!!!

userID:
1313773
Display Name:
lovetocook
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
9
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614252.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yummy - great flavor!  This recipe is not difficult but has a few steps.  I used a few different ingredients to make it a little healthier.  First, I used turkey bacon (I prefer the Louis Rich brand) which has less than half the fat of "real" bacon but still adds great flavor.  I also used 1 cup of 2% milk rather than cream but mixed about 4 tablespoons of cream with 1 tablespoon of flour to replace the thickness that a cup of cream would have added.  I did not use cilantro but added 2 dried bay leaves when I added the stock and simmered everything for about 20 minutes before I pureed (make sure not to puree the bay leaves if you use them).  I simmered the soup for another 10-15 minutes.  This recipe makes 8 generous size servings.  Make it a meal by serving in a bread bowl!  Great to freeze & reheat.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2005-01-02T16:36:41.593
helpfulCount:
0

text:
My hubby and I agree - this is absolutely the best potato soup we've ever eaten.   Out goes the recipe I've used for years.   I followed the recipe except for using instant mashed potato flakes to thicken instead of the flour.   So much easier, and doesn't detract from the flavors at all.   Just sprinkle in a little at a time until you reach the thickness you want.   Can't wait to try this on my son when he comes home from college on Christmas break.    ummmmm good.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is comfort food at its best and thank you for the recipe Karena! As usual, I tweaked this recipe a bit but not by much. The only changes I made was that I thickend it with about 1/2 cup instant mashed potatoes flakes, as opposed to the cream to save some calories, thereby leaving the potatoes in tact, as we prefer. I also added some shredded cabbage at the end, or almost any other vegetable would be fine. The basic flavor of this economical and savory soup is superb and I'm thrilled that I never have to search for another potato soup recipe again. This one has a permanent spot in my files & hubby raved about it too! Try a little Polish flair to it like I grew up with by adding the cabbage along with some savory brown mustard lightly drizzled over your serving. Yummy...this is the stuff that makes a tummy happy.

text:
This soup was pretty good.  I did not want to add meat, so I cooked a ham bone and added the broth to compensate for the bacon.  I did not have taragon, so I added thyme instead.  I also added an extra potato since I love to have plenty of potato chunks.  This is the best recipe I have used so far--even with all of the substitutions.  Very high in calories, but well worth it.

text:
Since I'm currently on a diet, I altered this recipe somewhat and it still turned out great.

I used 5 pieces of turkey bacon instead of 1 lb. of regular bacon, then sauteed the veggies in 1 tbsp. of light margarine.  I also used light margarine in the flour mixture and skim milk instead of heavy cream.

The soup had awesome flavor even with the subsitutions!

The taste of this soup was gppd, but it required a substantial amount of prep time.  I added carrots and used half & half instead of cream, and also cooked it in the slow cooker.  I'm not a cilantro fan, and omitted the herb.  I found that I had to jazz it up with bacon bits on top in order to add a little burst of flavor.  I also topped with shredded cheese and chives.  Will I make it again?  Definitely, if I have a lot of time on my hands on a blistery winter day.

text:
I concur with others' suggestions -- this soup doesn't have to be nearly as fattening as the recipe suggests, in order to taste great.  Cut the bacon in half, use fat-free half & half instead of heavy cream.  Make this if you're REALLY in the mood for some serious cooking, b/c your kitchen will be a mess when you're done an hour or so later!  Very good, but too much of a hassle to make except on rare occasions. Top with chives and cheddar cheese.

text:
This soup was very tasty.  I used Yukon Gold potatoes, and they were a bit too mealy.  My soup turned out more like very soft mashed potatoes.  Next time, I think I'll try a different type of potato, and I might add milk to thin it out a bit.  However, I love the flavor in this soup!  Give this recipe a try if you like baked potato soup!
